Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. diagrams.title: Air Intake Opening Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Air intake openings provide a way for outdoor air to enter a building and supply fresh air to its occupants. The ventilation can occur from either natural or mechanical ventilation.
When the intake air or exhaust system is not properly designed, contaminated air has the possibility of entering the building which would reduce the indoor air quality and potentially cause unwanted odors or even potential health issues for the buildings occupants.

diagrams.title: Bay and Oriel Windows
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Bay and Oriel Windows are considered to be wall projections by the building code. All projections must comply with the minimum distance from the fire separation line as defined in Table 705.2. Bay and Oriel window construction when of combustible material need to conform to the same requirements as would be required for the exterior wall from which it projects from. The buildings exterior wall requirements are typically based on Table 705.5 and depend on the buildings occupancy group, construction type and fire separation distance.

children.body:
The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.
Exceptions:
  1. In other than Group H occupancies, unlimited unprotected openings are permitted in the first story above grade plane where the wall faces one of the following:
    1. A street and has a fire separation distance of more than 15 feet (4572 mm).
    2. An unoccupied space. The unoccupied space shall be on the same lot or dedicated for public use, shall be not less than 30 feet (9144 mm) in width and shall have access from a street by a posted fire lane in accordance with the International Fire Code.
  2. Buildings whose exterior bearing walls, exterior nonbearing walls and exterior primary structural frame are not required to be fire-resistance rated shall be permitted to have unlimited unprotected openings.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

children.body:
Where openings are required to be protected, opening protectives shall comply with Section 716.
Exception: Opening protectives are not required where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and the exterior openings are protected by a water curtain using automatic sprinklers approved for that use.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Air Intake Opening Protection (IMC vs. UMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Uniform Mechanical Code, an air Intake is an opening in a building's envelope whose purpose is to allow outside air to be drawn into the structure to replace inside air that is removed by exhaust systems or to improve the quality of the inside air by providing a source of air having a lower concentration of odors, suspended particles, or heating content.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Where unprotected openings are permitted, windows and doors shall be constructed of any approved materials. Glazing shall conform to the requirements of Chapters 24 and 26.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

children.body:
Where both unprotected and protected openings are located in the exterior wall in any story of a building, the total area of openings shall be determined in accordance with the following:
(Equation 7-2)
Ap = Actual area of protected openings, or the equivalent area of protected openings, Ae (see Section 705.7).
ap = Allowable area of protected openings.
Au = Actual area of unprotected openings.
au = allowable area of unprotected openings.

Openings in exterior walls in adjacent stories shall be separated vertically to protect against fire spread on the exterior of the buildings where the openings are within 5 feet (1524 mm) of each other horizontally and the opening in the lower story is not a protected opening with a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. Such openings shall be separated vertically not less than 3 feet (914 mm) by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour, rated for exposure to fire from both sides, or by flame barriers that extend horizontally not less than 30 inches (762 mm) beyond the exterior wall. Flame barriers shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour. The unexposed surface temperature limitations specified in ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not apply to the flame barriers unless otherwise required by the provisions of this code.
Exceptions:
  1. This section shall not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section shall not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. Open parking garages.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

children.body:
For buildings on the same lot, opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour shall be provided in every opening that is less than 15 feet (4572 mm) vertically above the roof of an adjacent building or structure based on assuming an imaginary line between them. The opening protectives are required where the fire separation distances from the imaginary line to each building or structure are less than 15 feet (4572 mm).
Exceptions:
  1. Opening protectives are not required where the roof assembly of the adjacent building or structure has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour for a minimum distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) from the exterior wall facing the imaginary line and the entire length and span of the supporting elements for the fire-resistance-rated roof assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
  2. Buildings on the same lot and considered as portions of one building in accordance with Section 705.3 are not required to comply with Section 705.8.6.

diagrams.title: Buildings on Same Lot: Vertical Exposure
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Buildings on the same lot but that are of different heights may require protection of the upper windows against fire that could be coming from a fire at the adjacent lower building. This code section does not address a requirement for the wall itself to be fire rated, but the opening to have protection. Table 602 would govern the required fire rating based on the fire-separation distance. However, if the wall between the buildings is a fire wall, then 706.6.1 would apply, which requires a fire rating of the 15 feet that extend beyond the lower building.

children.body:
Joints made in or between exterior walls required by this section to have a fire-resistance rating shall comply with Section 715.
Exception: Joints in exterior walls that are permitted to have unprotected openings.
The void created at the intersection of a floor/ceiling assembly and an exterior curtain wall assembly shall be protected in accordance with Section 715.4.

diagrams.title: Side Clip Attachment: Bypass Wall Stud (Steel)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Proprietary or custom designed angles (clips) can be used to attach a metal stud bypassing the floor assembly. Bypass clips are used to attach exterior curtain wall studs to the building structure and provide either a rigid connection or deflecting connection for vertical building movement independent of the cold-formed steel framing.

Where curtain walls are extended on the outside of a spandrel member, a void can be created that could allow for the passage of smoke or flames. Special consideration of these conditions is required.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.body:
Penetrations by air ducts and air transfer openings in fire-resistance-rated exterior walls required to have protected openings shall comply with Section 717.
Exception: Foundation vents installed in accordance with this code are permitted.

diagrams.title: Vent Termination Locations at Ext. Walls (IMC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mechanical vent terminations are required to maintain minimum distances from openings so as not to contaminate fresh air intake into the building. Also verify requirements with the manufacturer's specifications.

children.body:
Parapets shall be provided on exterior walls of buildings.
Exceptions: A parapet need not be provided on an exterior wall where any of the following conditions exist:
  1. The wall is not required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Table 705.5 because of fire separation distance.
  2. The building has an area of not more than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) on any floor.
  3. Walls that terminate at roofs of not less than 2-hour fire-resistance-rated construction or where the roof, including the deck or slab and supporting construction, is constructed entirely of noncombustible materials.
  4. One-hour fire-resistance-rated exterior walls that terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab, provided that:
    1. Where the roof/ceiling framing elements are parallel to the walls, such framing and elements supporting such framing shall not be of less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a width of 4 feet (1220 mm) for Groups R and U and 10 feet (3048 mm) for other occupancies, measured from the interior side of the wall.
    2. Where roof/ceiling framing elements are not parallel to the wall, the entire span of such framing and elements supporting such framing shall not be of less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction.
    3. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the 1-hour fire-resistance-rated exterior wall for Groups R and U and 10 feet (3048 mm) for other occupancies, measured from the interior side of the wall.
    4. The entire building shall be provided with not less than a Class B roof covering.
  5. In Groups R-2 and R-3 where the entire building is provided with a Class C roof covering, the exterior wall shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck in Types III, IV and V construction, provided that one or both of the following criteria is met:
    1. The roof sheathing or deck is constructed of approved noncombustible materials or of fire-retardant-treated wood for a distance of 4 feet (1220 mm).
    2. The roof is protected with 0.625-inch (16 mm) Type X gypsum board directly beneath the underside of the roof sheathing or deck, supported by not less than nominal 2-inch (51 mm) ledgers attached to the sides of the roof framing members for a minimum distance of 4 feet (1220 mm).
  6. Where the wall is permitted to have not less than 25 percent of the exterior wall areas containing unprotected openings based on fire separation distance as determined in accordance with Section 705.8.

diagrams.title: Example: Conc. Parapet Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This example shows a concrete parapet wall that backs up the brick facade, and is secured to a concrete/metal deck.

children.body: Parapets shall have the same fire-resistance rating as that required for the supporting wall, and on any side adjacent to a roof surface, shall have noncombustible faces for the uppermost 18 inches (457 mm), including counterflashing and coping materials. The height of the parapet shall be not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above the point where the roof surface and the wall intersect. Where the roof slopes toward a parapet at a slope greater than 2 units vertical in 12 units horizontal (16.7-percent slope), the parapet shall extend to the same height as any portion of the roof within a fire separation distance where protection of wall openings is required, but the height shall be not less than 30 inches (762 mm).

diagrams.title: Weatherproofing Fire Rated vs. Other Parapet Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The coping and waterproofing for a fire rated wall at a parapet protect all layers of the required fire ratings, and cannot cause the reduction or elimination of these layers, such as the required thickness of plaster, across the full height of the parapet.

diagrams.title: Parapet Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.11.1 defines the required fire protection and height of parapet walls. The fire resistance rating of the parapet wall is required to be same as the wall below that is supporting the parapet. The wall below may have different ratings required for the interior and exterior sides depending on the construction type and fire separation distance.

Additional wall top protection of the parapet is required as follows:First, the top of the parapet needs to be protected by noncombustible coping. Second, on faces of the parapet adjacent to a roof the top 18" must be protected by a noncombustible facing. This requirement also applies to any counterflashing that may occur in the same region of the parapet wall face.

The minimum required parapet wall height is 30" above where the roof surface and wall intersect. The parapet height may need to be increased if the roof slopes towards the parapet at greater than 2:12 slope, or if the height of the roof at the fire separation distance that defines the limit of where protection of wall openings is greater than 30" above where the roof meets the parapet wall. In this case, the minimum parapet height is required to be the height of the roof at which the fire separation distance requires protection of wall openings.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Horiz. Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Fire walls have special requirements for horizontal continuity at or beyond the exterior face of the building. If the wall is not extended 18" beyond the face of the exterior wall, then special attention must be given to the interface and construction of the fire wall to extend into the construction of the exterior wall to the backside of the exterior sheathing or finishes. In addition the types of exterior sheathing or finishes determines the requirements for opening protection within four feet each side of the wall. If the angle of the intersecting walls are more than 180 degrees, it becomes more difficult for a fire to "end run" around the end of the fire wall, and requirements on these intersecting walls becomes less.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any opening in a fire wall is required to be protected. The maximum size of any single opening is 156 sq. ft., but the total length of openings is not permitted to exceed 25% of the length of entire wall. Party walls are not permitted to have any openings. Where the spaces on both sides of the fire wall are sprinklered with an NFPA13 system, then openings are permitted to exceed the 156 sq.ft. limit, but must still conform to the 25% limitation.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation required for podium buildings by Section 510.2, the fire wall may start at the top of the rated podium assembly.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. If the provisions of NFPA 221 are used, only allows this condition for Type I and II construction, whereas the building code does not explicitly say the entire building must be of Type I or II construction. It only addresses the roof construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Anchor Buildings and Mall Fire Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mall anchor buildings are to be separated from a mall building by fire walls in compliance with section 706. Where the anchor building is 3 or less stories above grade plane and the same occupancy as the mall tenant spaces a 2 hour rated fire barrier may be used in place of the fire walls. Where an anchor building is separated from an open mall building with an open mall the exterior walls of the anchor building need to comply with the requirements of table 705.5.

diagrams.title: Single Bldg. Classification (FHA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Fair Housing Act, dwellings that are built within a single structure but separated by a firewall are classified as a single building. Where the dwelling units are connected, such as by stairs or a walkway that is structurally tied to the main body of the building, they are also considered a single building and ground floor units in such buildings without elevators are covered.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers

children.body: Fire walls shall be constructed in accordance with Sections 706.2 through 706.11. The extent and location of such fire walls shall provide a complete separation. Where a fire wall separates occupancies that are required to be separated by a fire barrier wall, the most restrictive requirements of each separation shall apply.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

children.body:
Any wall located on a lot line between adjacent buildings, which is used or adapted for joint service between the two buildings, shall be constructed as a fire wall in accordance with Section 706. Party walls shall be constructed without openings and shall create separate buildings.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings in a party wall separating an anchor building and a mall shall be in accordance with Section 402.4.2.2.1.
  2. Party walls and fire walls are not required on lot lines dividing a building for ownership purposes where the aggregate height and area of the portions of the building located on both sides of the lot line do not exceed the maximum height and area requirements of this code. For the building official's review and approval, the official shall be provided with copies of dedicated access easements and contractual agreements that permit the owners of portions of the building located on either side of the lot line access to the other side for purposes of maintaining fire and life safety systems necessary for the operation of the building.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

children.body:
Fire walls shall be designed and constructed to allow collapse of the structure on either side without collapse of the wall under fire conditions. Fire walls designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA 221 shall be deemed to comply with this section.
Exception: In Seismic Design Categories D through F, where double fire walls are used in accordance with NFPA 221, floor and roof sheathing not exceeding 3/4 inch (19.05 mm) thickness shall be permitted to be continuous through the wall assemblies of light frame construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

children.body:
Fire walls shall be of any approved noncombustible materials.
Exception: Buildings of Type V construction.
Fire walls shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by Table 706.4.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

children.body:
Fire walls shall be continuous from exterior wall to exterior wall and shall extend not less than 18 inches (457 mm) beyond the exterior surface of exterior walls.
Exceptions:
  1. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of combustible exterior sheathing or siding provided that the exterior wall has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour for a horizontal distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  2. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of noncombustible exterior sheathing, exterior siding or other noncombustible exterior finishes provided that the sheathing, siding or other exterior noncombustible finish extends a horizontal distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall.
  3. Fire walls shall be permitted to terminate at the interior surface of noncombustible exterior sheathing where the building on each side of the fire wall is protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Horiz. Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Fire walls have special requirements for horizontal continuity at or beyond the exterior face of the building. If the wall is not extended 18" beyond the face of the exterior wall, then special attention must be given to the interface and construction of the fire wall to extend into the construction of the exterior wall to the backside of the exterior sheathing or finishes. In addition the types of exterior sheathing or finishes determines the requirements for opening protection within four feet each side of the wall. If the angle of the intersecting walls are more than 180 degrees, it becomes more difficult for a fire to "end run" around the end of the fire wall, and requirements on these intersecting walls becomes less.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections (Excpt. 2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

children.body:
Where the fire wall intersects exterior walls, the fire-resistance rating and opening protection of the exterior walls shall comply with one of the following:
  1. The exterior walls on both sides of the fire wall shall have a 1-hour fire-resistance rating with 3/4-hour protection where opening protection is required by Section 705.8. The fire-resistance rating of the exterior wall shall extend not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on each side of the intersection of the fire wall to exterior wall. Exterior wall intersections at fire walls that form an angle equal to or greater than 180 degrees (3.14 rad) do not need exterior wall protection.
  2. Buildings or spaces on both sides of the intersecting fire wall shall assume to have an imaginary lot line at the fire wall and extending beyond the exterior of the fire wall. The location of the assumed line in relation to the exterior walls and the fire wall shall be such that the exterior wall and opening protection meet the requirements set forth in Sections 705.5 and 705.8. Such protection is not required for exterior walls terminating at fire walls that form an angle equal to or greater than 180 degrees (3.14 rad).

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

children.body:
Fire walls shall extend to the outer edge of horizontal projecting elements such as balconies, roof overhangs, canopies, marquees and similar projections that are within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
Exceptions:
  1. Horizontal projecting elements without concealed spaces, provided that the exterior wall behind and below the projecting element has not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance not less than the depth of the projecting element on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  2. Noncombustible horizontal projecting elements with concealed spaces, provided that a minimum 1-hour fire-resistance-rated wall extends through the concealed space. The projecting element shall be separated from the building by not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance on each side of the fire wall equal to the depth of the projecting element. The wall is not required to extend under the projecting element where the building exterior wall is not less than 1-hour fire-resistance rated for a distance on each side of the fire wall equal to the depth of the projecting element. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.
  3. For combustible horizontal projecting elements with concealed spaces, the fire wall need only extend through the concealed space to the outer edges of the projecting elements. The exterior wall behind and below the projecting element shall be of not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction for a distance not less than the depth of the projecting elements on both sides of the fire wall. Openings within such exterior walls shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls at Horizontal Projections
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

T
he code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The function of a firewall is to separate adjacent building areas, sufficient to allow individual evaluation of building height and area concerns. Where exterior projecting construction features occur within 4 feet on either side of the fire wall / exterior wall intersection, the code prescribes methods to prevent fire extension around the fire wall. In general the fire wall should continue through the exterior wall and horizontal projection, to the outer edge of the projection.

The code allows three exceptions to the general requirement. Each exception mitigates the concern using 1-hour fire resistance rated construction at the exterior wall on either side of the fire wall. In each case, the 1 hour exterior wall must extend a distance not less than the depth of the projection. Openings within the prescribed distance shall be protected by 3/4 hour fire rated assemblies.

Exception 1 addresses exterior projections having no concealed space, regardless of combustible/noncombustible construction. Exception 2 addresses noncombustible projections that include concealed space. Exception 3 addresses combustible projections that include concealed space.

children.body:
Fire walls shall extend from the foundation to a termination point not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above both adjacent roofs.
Exceptions:
  1. Stepped buildings in accordance with Section 706.6.1.
  2. Two-hour fire-resistance-rated walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab, provided that:
    1. The lower roof assembly within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the wall has not less than a 1-hour fire-resistance rating and the entire length and span of supporting elements for the rated roof assembly has a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
    2. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
    3. Each building shall be provided with not less than a Class B roof covering.
  3. Walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of noncombustible roof sheathing, deck or slabs where both buildings are provided with not less than a Class B roof covering. Openings in the roof shall not be located within 4 feet (1220 mm) of the fire wall.
  4. In buildings of Types III, IV and V construction, walls shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of combustible roof sheathing or decks, provided that all of the following requirements are met:
    1. Roof openings are not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) from the fire wall.
    2. The roof is covered with a minimum Class B roof covering.
    3. The roof sheathing or deck is constructed of fire-retardant-treated wood for a distance of 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the wall or the roof is protected with 5/8-inch (15.9 mm) Type X gypsum board directly beneath the underside of the roof sheathing or deck, supported by not less than 2-inch (51 mm) nominal ledgers attached to the sides of the roof framing members for a distance of not less than 4 feet (1220 mm) on both sides of the fire wall.
  5. In buildings designed in accordance with Section 510.2, fire walls located above the 3-hour horizontal assembly required by Section 510.2, Item 1 shall be permitted to extend from the top of this horizontal assembly.
  6. Buildings with sloped roofs in accordance with Section 706.6.2.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation required for podium buildings by Section 510.2, the fire wall may start at the top of the rated podium assembly.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. If the provisions of NFPA 221 are used, only allows this condition for Type I and II construction, whereas the building code does not explicitly say the entire building must be of Type I or II construction. It only addresses the roof construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

children.body:
Where a fire wall also serves as an exterior wall for a building and separates buildings having different roof levels, such wall shall terminate at a point not less than 30 inches (762 mm) above the lower roof level. Exterior walls above the fire wall extending more than 30 inches (762 mm) above the lower roof shall be of not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction from both sides with openings protected by fire assemblies having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. Portions of the exterior walls greater than 15 feet (4572 mm) above the lower roof shall be of nonfire-resistance-rated construction unless otherwise rated construction is required by other provisions of this code.
Exception: A fire wall serving as part of an exterior wall that separates buildings having different roof levels shall be permitted to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab of the lower roof, provided that Items 1, 2 and 3 are met. The exterior wall above the fire wall is not required to be of fire-resistance-rated construction unless required by other provisions of this code.
  1. The lower roof assembly within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the fire wall has not less than a 1-hour fire-resistance rating.
  2. The entire length and span of supporting elements for the rated roof assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1 hour.
  3. Openings in the lower roof shall not be located within 10 feet (3048 mm) of the fire wall.

Where a fire wall serves as an interior wall for a building, and the roof on one side or both sides of the fire wall slopes toward the fire wall at a slope greater than 2 units vertical in 12 units horizontal (2:12), the fire wall shall extend to a height equal to the height of the roof located 4 feet (1219 mm) from the fire wall plus 30 inches (762 mm). The extension of the fire wall shall be not less than 30 inches (762 mm).

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Exception 6
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected or is of non-combustible material. In the event the building is located above a 3 hr rated horizontal separation the fire wall may start at the top of the rated assembly. When roofs on either side of the firewall slope towards the fire-wall with a slope exceeding 2 in 12 the fire wall height needs to be at least 30" above the roof deck within 4' of the firewall.

children.body: Adjacent combustible members entering into a concrete or masonry fire wall from opposite sides shall not have less than a 4-inch (102 mm) distance between embedded ends. Where combustible members frame into hollow walls or walls of hollow units, hollow spaces shall be solidly filled for the full thickness of the wall and for a distance not less than 4 inches (102 mm) above, below and between the structural members, with noncombustible materials approved for fireblocking.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls Supporting Combustible Framing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combustible members embedded in concrete or masonry walls are required to maintain a minimum of solid or fireblocked material between ends of adjacent wood members. This prevents a condition where the combustible material burns out and creates an opening through which smoke, heat and fire can pass.

children.body:
Each opening through a fire wall shall be protected in accordance with Section 716 and shall not exceed 156 square feet (15 m2). The aggregate width of openings at any floor level shall not exceed 25 percent of the length of the wall.
Exceptions:
  1. Openings are not permitted in party walls constructed in accordance with Section 706.1.1.
  2. Openings shall not be limited to 156 square feet (15 m2) where both buildings are equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Fire Walls: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any opening in a fire wall is required to be protected. The maximum size of any single opening is 156 sq. ft., but the total length of openings is not permitted to exceed 25% of the length of entire wall. Party walls are not permitted to have any openings. Where the spaces on both sides of the fire wall are sprinklered with an NFPA13 system, then openings are permitted to exceed the 156 sq.ft. limit, but must still conform to the 25% limitation.

diagrams.title: Example: Hollow Metal Jamb - 2hr Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated assemblies at hollow metal door jambs should be detailed to maintain the fire rating at the interface of the door jamb and a 2-hr wall assembly. This is one example of how this can be accomplished. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD NO. FR3.03

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot - Excpt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 addresses the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already has a building on it. One has to have an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines to apply the section correctly. To comply with the base condition the designer needs to establish a fire separation line on the site that is in compliance with the existing buildings exterior wall and opening protectives. Once that line is located the new building may be designed as if the newly established line is a property line. Exception 1 allows for the new building and existing buildings to be considered one structure and eliminates the fire separation protectives required by the imaginary fire separation line of the base condition.

Exception 1 applies limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type on the site.

Exception 2 only applies when an S-2 parking garage of type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. Zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage is required for the exception. 1-1/2 hr fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts with the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with 706.8 which limits single opening size and aggregate width of openings relative the wall length.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Penetrations of fire walls shall comply with Section 714.
Joints made in or between fire walls shall comply with Section 715.

Ducts and air transfer openings shall not penetrate fire walls.
Exception: Penetrations by ducts and air transfer openings of fire walls that are not on a lot line shall be allowed provided that the penetrations comply with Section 717. The size and aggregate width of all openings shall not exceed the limitations of Section 706.8.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any opening in a fire wall is required to be protected. The maximum size of any single opening is 156 sq. ft., but the total length of openings is not permitted to exceed 25% of the length of entire wall. Party walls are not permitted to have any openings. Where the spaces on both sides of the fire wall are sprinklered with an NFPA13 system, then openings are permitted to exceed the 156 sq.ft. limit, but must still conform to the 25% limitation.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers
Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structural members and assemblies that support a fire barrier are required to have the same or higher fire-resistance rating as the barrier being supported. Hollow vertical spaces within the barrier need to be fireblocked at every floor level as per Section 718.2. There is an exception for assemblies supporting fire barriers for tank storage where a maximum fire-resistance rating of 2 hours, or the minimum specified by Table 601 for the building type is required. There is an exception for construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB, and VB unless mandated by other code sections.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Construction (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit passageways are to provide a safe way to exit a building from an interior exit stairway or ramp, to protect occupants the enclosure must provide fire protection. The fire rating of the exit passageways walls, floors, and ceilings shall be not less than 1 hour or the rating of the exit stairway or ramp enclosure, which ever is greater. Exit passageway walls are required to be constructed as fire-barriers in accordance with section 707. Exit passageway floors and ceilings, horizontal assemblies, are required to be constructed in accordance with section 711.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Fire Barriers: Building Code vs. Life Safety Code
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In the Life Safety Code a fire barrier is defined as a membrane with a fire protection rating, the membrane may be utilized to provide vertical or horizontal separation. The life Safety Code has a separate definition for a Fire Barrier Wall that is similar to the Building Code's definition of a Fire Barrier. In the building code a fire barrier is defined as a fire-resistance rated wall assembly.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

diagrams.title: Fire-Resistance Ratings of Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control areas are required to be separated from one another by either fire barriers or horizontal assemblies. The fire barrier fire-resistance rating is determined in Table 414.2.2 and depends on the percentage of the maximum allowable quantity that will be stored within the control area and the story the control area is located on. Horizontal assemblies and their associated supporting structure are required to have a 2 hour fire-resistance rating except in buildings of type IIA, IIIA, IV or VA construction that are 3 stories or less and have a sprinkler system install throughout.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Fire Barrier Continuity
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In this example, a 1-hour fire barrier interesects a 2-hour horizontal floor assembly. The fire barrier must extend up through any concealed spaces in the floor ceiling assembly. Certain exceptions exist for shaft, stairway and exit-passageway enclosures.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Vertical Offsets in Podium Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a vertical offset is part of a horizontal assembly utilized to establish separate buildings the offset is required to be constructed as a 3 hour minimum fire-resistance rated fire barrier per Section 707. Structural elements that support the fire-barrier need protection equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier being supported.

diagrams.title: Vertical Offsets in Podium Horizontal Assemblies - Cross Section
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a vertical offset is part of a horizontal assembly utilized to establish separate buildings the offset is required to be constructed as a 3 hour minimum fire-resistance rated fire barrier per Section 707. Structural elements that support the fire-barrier need protection equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier being supported.

diagrams.title: Spaces Under Bleachers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Protection of storage and other spaces under bleachers prevents unseen danger to the occupants above from an unseen fire below. If bleachers are solid, they may prevent knowledge of a dangerous situation. Conversely, if bleachers are able to allow the passage of smoke, this could also provide a dangerous situation during evacuation to occupants above. Therefore, except for low hazard situations, a one-hour separation (both vertical and horizontal) is required to protect the occupants above.

diagrams.title: Enclosure of Atriums: Exception 3 - Smoke Control System
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers
Voids at Intersections of Fire Barriers
