diagrams.descriptionHtml: Smoke Partition, Smoke Barrier (NFPA 101) - Smoke partitions and smoke barriers are both intended to serve the same purpose, limit the transfer of smoke through a building in case of a fire incident. A smoke partition can be built from the floor and may stop at a membrane ceiling as long as that ceiling is designed to limit smoke transfer. Openings, penetrations, and joints in a smoke partition, must simply limit the transfer of smoke. Smoke barriers are more restrictive of smoke transfer than are partitions. A smoke barrier must extend all the way to the roof, or floor, above, and through all concealed spaces. Though the smoke partition does not have to be fire-rated the ducts, joints, penetrations, and other openings must be installed using a UL listed system. Fire barriers can be used as smoke barriers. Where this is the case, the minimum fire rating and construction requirements of 8.3 and 8.5 must apply.

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partitions vs. Smoke Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE PARTITION. A wall assembly that extends from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above or to the underside of the ceiling above where the ceiling membrane is constructed to limit the transfer of smoke.
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

diagrams.title: Alterations: Smoke Compartments in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where an alteration occurs in an group I-2 occupancy in a story of the building that will provide for more than 30 patience, it is required to subdivide the story into two or more smoke containment compartments. The smoke compartment separation is required to be achieved by smoke barrier wall constructed in accordance with 407.5 of the Building Code.

children.body: Vertical and horizontal smoke barriers shall comply with this section.
Smoke barriers shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

A 1-hour fire-resistance rating is required for smoke barriers.
Exception: Smoke barriers constructed of minimum 0.10-inch-thick (2.5 mm) steel in Group I-3 buildings.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

children.body:
Smoke barriers shall form an effective membrane continuous from the top of the foundation or floor/ceiling assembly below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above, including continuity through concealed spaces, such as those found above suspended ceilings, and interstitial structural and mechanical spaces. The supporting construction shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the wall or floor supported in buildings of other than Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction. Smoke-barrier walls used to separate smoke compartments shall comply with Section 709.4.1. Smoke-barrier walls used to enclose areas of refuge in accordance with Section 1009.6.4 or to enclose elevator lobbies in accordance with Section 405.4.3, 3007.6.2, or 3008.6.2 shall comply with Section 709.4.2.
Exception: Smoke-barrier walls are not required in interstitial spaces where such spaces are designed and constructed with ceilings or exterior walls that provide resistance to the passage of fire and smoke equivalent to that provided by the smoke-barrier walls.

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors.

source: hcai.ca.gov OPD CL2.10

children.body: Smoke-barrier assemblies used to separate smoke compartments shall form an effective membrane enclosure that is continuous from an outside wall or smoke barrier wall to an outside wall or another smoke barrier wall and to the horizontal assemblies.

Smoke-barrier walls used to enclose areas of refuge in accordance with Section 1009.6.4, or to enclose elevator lobbies in accordance with Section 405.4.3, 3007.6.2, or 3008.6.2, shall form an effective membrane enclosure that terminates at a fire barrier wall having a level of fire protection rating not less than 1 hour, another smoke barrier wall or an outside wall. A smoke and draft control door assembly as specified in Section 716.2.2.1.1 shall not be required at each elevator hoistway door opening or at each exit doorway between an area of refuge and the exit enclosure.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers: Elevator Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

Sound-rated partitions are often used as smoke barriers because the assembly is specifically designed to resist the passage of air, which also transmits sound. When properly constructed with penetrations and joints treated to prevent air leakage, similar to the methods used for sound control, the partition can effectively prevent smoke passage as well.

diagrams.title: Areas of Refuge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Areas of refuge provide fire and smoke protected areas where those unable to use stairs can register a call for help and await evacuation assistance. These areas must provide direct access to exit stairways and can be located adjacent to stairway enclosures or on stair landings outside the minimum exit width. Incidentally, the New York City Building Code refers to these as Areas of Rescue Assistance.

If areas of refuge are outside of an exit enclosure, they must be designed to minimize the intrusion of smoke by use of a smoke barrier or horizontal exit.

Conditions where areas of refuge have changed over various code cycles. Verify the requirement for the area of refuge so that the building is not altered to be out of compliance with the code it was constructed under.

children.displayTitle: 709.4.2 Smoke-Barrier Walls Enclosing Areas of Refuge or Elevator Lobbies
children.titleText: Smoke-Barrier Walls Enclosing Areas of Refuge or Elevator Lobbies

children.body:
Openings in a smoke barrier shall be protected in accordance with Section 716.
Exceptions:
  1. In Group I-1, Condition 2, Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, where a pair of opposite-swinging doors are installed across a corridor in accordance with Section 709.5.1, the doors shall not be required to be protected in accordance with Section 716. The doors shall be close fitting within operational tolerances, and shall not have a center mullion or undercuts in excess of 3/4 inch (19.1 mm), louvers or grilles. The doors shall have head and jamb stops, and astragals or rabbets at meeting edges. Where permitted by the door manufacturer's listing, positive-latching devices are not required. Factory-applied or field-applied protective plates are not required to be labeled.
  2. In Group I-1, Condition 2, Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, special purpose horizontal sliding, accordion or folding doors installed in accordance with Section 1010.3.3 and protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies

children.body: In Group I-2 and ambulatory care facilities, where doors protecting openings in smoke barriers are installed across a corridor and have hold-open devices, the doors shall be automatic-closing in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6. Such doors shall have a vision panel with fire-protection-rated glazing materials in fire-protection-rated frames, the area of which shall not exceed that tested.

diagrams.title: Alterations: Smoke Compartments in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where an alteration occurs in an group I-2 occupancy in a story of the building that will provide for more than 30 patience, it is required to subdivide the story into two or more smoke containment compartments. The smoke compartment separation is required to be achieved by smoke barrier wall constructed in accordance with 407.5 of the Building Code.

children.displayTitle: 709.5.1 Group I-2 and Ambulatory Care Facilities
children.titleText: Group I-2 and Ambulatory Care Facilities

children.body: Penetrations of smoke barriers shall comply with Section 714.
Joints made in or between smoke barriers shall comply with Section 715.
Penetrations in a smoke barrier by ducts and air transfer openings shall comply with Section 717.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers and Smoke Partitions (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The Life Safety Code defines smoke barriers and smoke partitions as follows:

Smoke BarrierA continuous membrane, or a membrane with discontinuities created by protected openings, where such membrane is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

Smoke PartitionA continuous membrane that is designed to form a barrier to limit the transfer of smoke.

Smoke Barriers can be either a horizontal or vertical assembly, and compartmentalizes buildings, since the continuity requirements require extending to outside walls or to another smoke barrier. Smoke partitions have a continuity requirement that only requires continuity from the floor to ceiling or floor above, and does not have a horizontal continuity requirement defining the extent of the partition in plan. Therefore, because of this, and the general definition of "partition", a smoke partition is only a wall section. It is intended to provide a more localized prevention of lateral smoke passage.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers / Partitions: Requirements (NFPA)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Smoke Partition, Smoke Barrier (NFPA 101) - Smoke partitions and smoke barriers are both intended to serve the same purpose, limit the transfer of smoke through a building in case of a fire incident. A smoke partition can be built from the floor and may stop at a membrane ceiling as long as that ceiling is designed to limit smoke transfer. Openings, penetrations, and joints in a smoke partition, must simply limit the transfer of smoke. Smoke barriers are more restrictive of smoke transfer than are partitions. A smoke barrier must extend all the way to the roof, or floor, above, and through all concealed spaces. Though the smoke partition does not have to be fire-rated the ducts, joints, penetrations, and other openings must be installed using a UL listed system. Fire barriers can be used as smoke barriers. Where this is the case, the minimum fire rating and construction requirements of 8.3 and 8.5 must apply.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partitions vs. Smoke Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE PARTITION. A wall assembly that extends from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above or to the underside of the ceiling above where the ceiling membrane is constructed to limit the transfer of smoke.
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

children.body: Smoke partitions installed as required elsewhere in the code shall comply with this section.
The walls shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

children.body: Unless required elsewhere in the code, smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating.

children.body: Openings in smoke partitions shall comply with Sections 710.5.1 through 710.5.3.

children.body: Windows in smoke partitions shall be sealed to resist the free passage of smoke or be automatic-closing upon detection of smoke.
Doors in smoke partitions shall comply with Sections 710.5.2.1 through 710.5.2.3.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies

children.body:
Doors in smoke partitions shall not include louvers.
Exception: Where permitted in accordance with Section 407.3.1.1.

Where required elsewhere in the code, doors in smoke partitions shall meet the requirements for a smoke and draft control door assembly tested in accordance with UL 1784. The air leakage rate of the door assembly shall not exceed 3.0 cubic feet per minute per square foot [0.015424 m3/(s × m2)] of door opening at 0.10 inch (24.9 Pa) of water for both the ambient temperature test and the elevated temperature exposure test. Installation of smoke doors shall be in accordance with NFPA 105.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft)- 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

children.body: Smoke and draft control doors complying only with UL 1784 shall be permitted to show the letter "S" on the manufacturer's labeling.
children.displayTitle: 710.5.2.2.1 Smoke and Draft Control Door Labeling
children.titleText: Smoke and Draft Control Door Labeling

children.body: Where required elsewhere in the code, doors in smoke partitions shall be self- or automatic-closing by smoke detection in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6.

children.body:
Where pass-through openings are provided in smoke partitions in Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancies, such openings shall comply with the following:
  1. The smoke compartment in which the pass-through openings occur does not contain a patient care suite or sleeping room.
  2. Pass-through openings are installed in a wall, door or vision panel that is not required to have a fire-resistance rating.
  3. The top of the pass-through opening is located a maximum of 48 inches (1219 mm) above the floor.
  4.  The aggregate area of all such pass-through openings within a single room shall not exceed 80 square inches (0.05 m2).
children.displayTitle: 710.5.3 Pass-Through Openings in Group I-2, Condition 2
children.titleText: Pass-Through Openings in Group I-2, Condition 2

children.body: The space around penetrating items shall be filled with an approved material to limit the free passage of smoke.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

children.body: Joints shall be filled with an approved material to limit the free passage of smoke.

The space around a duct penetrating a smoke partition shall be filled with an approved material to limit the free passage of smoke. Air transfer openings in smoke partitions shall be provided with a smoke damper complying with Section 717.3.2.2.
Exception: Where the installation of a smoke damper will interfere with the operation of a required smoke control system in accordance with Section 909, approved alternative protection shall be utilized.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Construction (IBC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit passageways are to provide a safe way to exit a building from an interior exit stairway or ramp, to protect occupants the enclosure must provide fire protection. The fire rating of the exit passageways walls, floors, and ceilings shall be not less than 1 hour or the rating of the exit stairway or ramp enclosure, which ever is greater. Exit passageway walls are required to be constructed as fire-barriers in accordance with section 707. Exit passageway floors and ceilings, horizontal assemblies, are required to be constructed in accordance with section 711.

diagrams.title: Fire-Resistance Ratings of Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control areas are required to be separated from one another by either fire barriers or horizontal assemblies. The fire barrier fire-resistance rating is determined in Table 414.2.2 and depends on the percentage of the maximum allowable quantity that will be stored within the control area and the story the control area is located on. Horizontal assemblies and their associated supporting structure are required to have a 2 hour fire-resistance rating except in buildings of type IIA, IIIA, IV or VA construction that are 3 stories or less and have a sprinkler system install throughout.

diagrams.title: Parapet Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.11.1 defines the required fire protection and height of parapet walls. The fire resistance rating of the parapet wall is required to be same as the wall below that is supporting the parapet. The wall below may have different ratings required for the interior and exterior sides depending on the construction type and fire separation distance.

Additional wall top protection of the parapet is required as follows:First, the top of the parapet needs to be protected by noncombustible coping. Second, on faces of the parapet adjacent to a roof the top 18" must be protected by a noncombustible facing. This requirement also applies to any counterflashing that may occur in the same region of the parapet wall face.

The minimum required parapet wall height is 30" above where the roof surface and wall intersect. The parapet height may need to be increased if the roof slopes towards the parapet at greater than 2:12 slope, or if the height of the roof at the fire separation distance that defines the limit of where protection of wall openings is greater than 30" above where the roof meets the parapet wall. In this case, the minimum parapet height is required to be the height of the roof at which the fire separation distance requires protection of wall openings.

diagrams.title: Draftstopping in Floors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

children.body: Horizontal assemblies shall comply with Section 711.2. Nonfire-resistance-rated floor and roof assemblies shall comply with Section 711.3.
Horizontal assemblies shall comply with Sections 711.2.1 through 711.2.6.

diagrams.title: Spaces Under Bleachers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Protection of storage and other spaces under bleachers prevents unseen danger to the occupants above from an unseen fire below. If bleachers are solid, they may prevent knowledge of a dangerous situation. Conversely, if bleachers are able to allow the passage of smoke, this could also provide a dangerous situation during evacuation to occupants above. Therefore, except for low hazard situations, a one-hour separation (both vertical and horizontal) is required to protect the occupants above.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Steel Floor / Roof with Metal Deck: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Composite steel and concrete deck construction has steel decking spanning between steel beams. These steel beams have welded studs that create an interface with the concrete. This causes the steel beam and the steel deck to structurally operate as a single system, similar to a T-beam concrete beam/slab system. The concrete may have embedded rebar for masonry parapets or embeds for things such as bracing or suspended ceiling systems. Coordination with the Structural Engineer of Record is necessary to ensure the proper assembly is selected to provide the proper fire ratings. In addition, Sprayed Fire-Resistant Materials may be required on the underside of the deck to provide the requisite resistance rating.

diagrams.title: Structure-Borne Sound
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structure borne sound is sound transferred through the assembly by the impact or vibration of the actual phyisical materials. Some methods to reduce this sound transmission includes sound reducing mats between the flooring and the substrate on top of the floor. Also, the use of resilient light gauge metal channels on the bottom of joists can also help reduce transmission of structure borne sound.

diagrams.title: Fire-Resistance Ratings of Control Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Control areas are required to be separated from one another by either fire barriers or horizontal assemblies. The fire barrier fire-resistance rating is determined in Table 414.2.2 and depends on the percentage of the maximum allowable quantity that will be stored within the control area and the story the control area is located on. Horizontal assemblies and their associated supporting structure are required to have a 2 hour fire-resistance rating except in buildings of type IIA, IIIA, IV or VA construction that are 3 stories or less and have a sprinkler system install throughout.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings: Conc. Slabs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Life Safety Code, "Fire resistance-rated floor and roof assemblies shall be classified as restrained or unrestrained in accordance with ASTM E119, Standard Test Methods for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials, or ANSI/UL 263, Standard for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials', or other approved test methods. The construction shall be considered restrained only where a registered design professional has furnished the authority having jurisdiction with satisfactory documentation verifying that the construction is restrained. The classification of fire resistance-rated floor and roof construction shall be identified on the plans as restrained or unrestrained."

Restraint is provided when adjacent structural elements not under the influence of a fire are able to provide lateral restraint to prevent the expansion of materials in the plane of a roof or floor assembly, such as a concrete slab, because of a fire below.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

children.body: Assemblies shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.
Assemblies shall be continuous without vertical openings, except as permitted by this section and Section 712.

The supporting construction shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the horizontal assembly supported.
Exception: In buildings of Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction, the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be fire-resistance rated at the following:
  1. Horizontal assemblies at the separations of incidental uses as specified by Table 509.1 provided that the required fire-resistance rating does not exceed 1 hour.
  2. Horizontal assemblies at the separations of dwelling units and sleeping units as required by Section 420.3.
  3. Horizontal assemblies at smoke barriers constructed in accordance with Section 709.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

children.body: The fire-resistance rating of horizontal assemblies shall comply with Sections 711.2.4.1 through 711.2.4.6 but shall be not less than that required by the building type of construction.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

diagrams.title: Rooftop Structures:  Fire-Resistance Ratings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Roof construction and associated supports are required to comply with table 601. Where a roof supports a rooftop structure the fire-resistance rating of the roof and its associated supporting members may not be reduced by one hour as noted in table note "a".

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

children.body: Where the horizontal assembly separates mixed occupancies, the assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by Section 508.4 based on the occupancies being separated.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

children.body: Where the horizontal assembly separates a single occupancy into different fire areas, the assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by Section 707.3.10.

diagrams.title: Example: Fire Areas (Group M)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Area: The aggregate floor area enclosed and bounded by fire walls, fire barriers, exterior walls or horizontal assemblies of a building. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the fire area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor next above.

When sprinklers are required for a fire area, it does not necessarily make it a "sprinklered building" for use in Chapter 5, unless it is "Sprinklered Throughout" in accordance with NFPA 13, 13R or 13D, as applicable. In addition, the separations are also not necessarily the same concept as separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if the most stringent of each fire rating requirements are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

children.body:
Horizontal assemblies serving as dwelling or sleeping unit separations in accordance with Section 420.3 shall be not less than 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction.
Exception: Horizontal assemblies separating dwelling units and sleeping units shall be not less than 1/2-hour fire-resistance-rated construction in a building of Types IIB, IIIB and VB construction, where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
Where the horizontal assembly is required to be a smoke barrier, the assembly shall comply with Section 709.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions

children.body: Where the horizontal assembly separates incidental uses from the remainder of the building, the assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by Section 509.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

children.body: Where a horizontal assembly is required by other sections of this code, the assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than that required by that section.

Where the weight of lay-in ceiling panels, used as part of fire-resistance-rated floor/ceiling or roof/ceiling assemblies, is not adequate to resist an upward force of 1 pound per square foot (48 Pa), wire or other approved devices shall be installed above the panels to prevent vertical displacement under such upward force.

In 1-hour fire-resistance-rated floor/ceiling assemblies, the ceiling membrane is not required to be installed over unusable crawl spaces. In 1-hour fire-resistance-rated roof assemblies, the floor membrane is not required to be installed where unusable attic space occurs above.
Nonfire-resistance-rated floor, floor/ceiling, roof and roof/ceiling assemblies shall comply with Sections 711.3.1 and 711.3.2.
Assemblies shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.
Assemblies shall be continuous without vertical openings, except as permitted by Section 712.

diagrams.title: Escalator Openings (New Const.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To protect occupants on the floor above from fire and smoke passing through escalator floor openings the code limits the size of the floor opening for an escalator to twice the projected area of the escalator. The code requires a draft curtain to limit smoke's ability to migrate up to the floor above. To prevent a fire from spreading through the escalator opening closely spaced sprinklers are required around the opening. Escalator floor openings may not connect more than 4 stories except in Group B and M occupancies.

diagrams.title: Framing Around Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Joists that must be cut short because of an opening must have a header to carry it's load to the adjacent continuous joists. Because of the increased load those continuous joists have, they must have increased capacity. This is a prescriptive measure. As openings increase in size, the larger the load on the boundary members of the opening. Very large openings may require a design by a qualified design professional.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

children.body: Each vertical opening shall comply in accordance with one of the protection methods in Sections 712.1.1 through 712.1.16.
Vertical openings contained entirely within a shaft enclosure complying with Section 713 shall be permitted.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

children.body: Unconcealed vertical openings totally within an individual residential dwelling unit and connecting four stories or less shall be permitted.

Where a building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, vertical openings for escalators or stairways which are not a portion of the means of egress shall be permitted where protected in accordance with Section 712.1.3.1 or 712.1.3.2.

Protection by a draft curtain and closely spaced sprinklers in accordance with NFPA 13 shall be permitted where the area of the vertical opening between stories does not exceed twice the horizontal projected area of the escalator or stairway. In other than Groups B and M, this application is limited to openings that do not connect more than four stories.

diagrams.title: Escalator Openings (New Const.)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To protect occupants on the floor above from fire and smoke passing through escalator floor openings the code limits the size of the floor opening for an escalator to twice the projected area of the escalator. The code requires a draft curtain to limit smoke's ability to migrate up to the floor above. To prevent a fire from spreading through the escalator opening closely spaced sprinklers are required around the opening. Escalator floor openings may not connect more than 4 stories except in Group B and M occupancies.

children.body: Protection of the vertical opening by approved shutters at every penetrated floor shall be permitted in accordance with this section. The shutters shall be of noncombustible construction and have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1.5 hours. The shutter shall be so constructed as to close immediately upon the actuation of a smoke detector installed in accordance with Section 907.3.1 and shall completely shut off the well opening. Escalators shall cease operation when the shutter begins to close. The shutter shall operate at a speed of not more than 30 feet per minute (152.4 mm/s) and shall be equipped with a sensitive leading edge to arrest its progress where in contact with any obstacle, and to continue its progress on release therefrom.
Penetrations, concealed and unconcealed, shall be permitted where protected in accordance with Section 714.

diagrams.title: Horiz. Assy. Through Penetrations: Ex. 2 & 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Through-penetration firestop system:An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

diagrams.title: Horiz. Assy. Through Penetrations: Ex. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Through-penetration firestop system:An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

children.body: Joints shall be permitted where complying with Section 712.1.5.1 or 712.1.5.2, as applicable.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.body: Joints made in or between horizontal assemblies shall comply with Section 715. The void created at the intersection of a floor/ceiling assembly and an exterior curtain wall assembly shall be permitted where protected in accordance with Section 715.4.
children.displayTitle: 712.1.5.1 Joints in or Between Horizontal Assemblies
children.titleText: Joints in or Between Horizontal Assemblies

children.body:
Joints in or between floor assemblies without a required fire-resistance rating shall be permitted where they comply with one of the following:
  1. The joint shall be concealed within the cavity of a wall.
  2. The joint shall be located above a ceiling.
  3. The joint shall be sealed, treated or covered with an approved material or system to resist the free passage of flame and the products of combustion.
Exception: Joints meeting one of the exceptions specified in Section 715.3.
children.displayTitle: 712.1.5.2 Joints in or Between Nonfire-Resistance-Rated Floor Assemblies
children.titleText: Joints in or Between Nonfire-Resistance-Rated Floor Assemblies

children.body: Penetrations by ducts and air transfer openings shall be protected in accordance with Section 717. Grease ducts shall be protected in accordance with the International Mechanical Code.

Atriums complying with Section 404 that connect two or more stories in Group I-2 or I-3 occupancies or three or more stories in other occupancies shall be permitted.
Exceptions:
  1. Atriums shall not be permitted within Group H occupancies.
  2. Balconies or stories within Groups A-1, A-4 and A-5 and mezzanines that comply with Section 505 shall not be considered a story as it applies to this section
Approved vertical openings for masonry chimneys shall be permitted where the annular space is fireblocked at each floor level in accordance with Section 718.2.5.

In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications specified in this section shall be permitted if the opening complies with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

children.body: Vertical openings in parking garages for automobile ramps, elevators and duct systems shall comply with Section 712.1.10.1, 712.1.10.2 or 712.1.10.3, as applicable.
Vertical openings for automobile ramps in parking garages shall be permitted where constructed in accordance with Sections 406.5 and 406.6.
Vertical openings for elevator hoistways in parking garages that serve only the parking garage, and complying with Sections 406.5 and 406.6, respectively, shall be permitted.

Vertical openings for mechanical exhaust or supply duct systems in parking garages complying with Sections 406.5 and 406.6, respectively, shall be permitted to be unenclosed where such duct system is contained within and serves only the parking garage.
Vertical openings between a mezzanine complying with Section 505 and the floor below shall be permitted.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

children.body: Vertical openings containing exit access stairways or ramps in accordance with Section 1019 shall be permitted.
Vertical openings for floor fire doors and access doors shall be permitted where protected by Section 712.1.13.1 or 712.1.13.2.

Horizontal fire door assemblies used to protect openings in fire-resistance-rated horizontal assemblies shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 288, and shall achieve a fire-resistance rating not less than the assembly being penetrated. Horizontal fire door assemblies shall be labeled by an approved agency. The label shall be permanently affixed and shall specify the manufacturer, the test standard and the fire-resistance rating.

Access doors shall be permitted in ceilings of fire-resistance-rated floor/ceiling and roof/ceiling assemblies, provided that such doors are tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 as horizontal assemblies and labeled by an approved agency for such purpose.
In Group I-3 occupancies, vertical openings shall be permitted in accordance with Section 408.5.

Skylights and other penetrations through a fire-resistance-rated roof deck or slab are permitted to be unprotected, provided that the structural integrity of the fire-resistance-rated roof assembly is maintained. Unprotected skylights shall not be permitted in roof assemblies required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Section 705.8.6. The supporting construction shall be protected to afford the required fire-resistance rating of the horizontal assembly supported.

diagrams.title: Min. Skylight Fenestration Area (ASHRAE)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
To ensure that adequate daylighting is taken advantage of in large commercial spaces ASHRAE provides skylight opening guidelines. The section applied to spaces greater than 2500 sf and applies to just about every commercial, recreational or assembly type space. The skylight area that is required may calculated in two different ways and may be either:
A: a skylight area of 3% of the daylight area when the Visible Transmittance of the skylight is 0.40 and greater or
B: a skylight effective aperture of 1% of the daylight area
Lighting provided in the daylight area when greater than 150 watts is required to be controlled by automatic daylight responsive controls in accordance with 9.4.1.1(f).

diagrams.title: Sprinklers at Skylights
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Skylights present a possible delay to sprinkler activation when their volume is excessive. This section establishes conditions under which no sprinkler is within the skylight ceiling recess.

The criteria apply to all sprinkler systems, regardless of design basis (LH, OH, EH). Skylights up to 32 s.f. (horizontal project area) that are separated by 10 feet from adjacent skylights or ceiling pockets need only have compliant sprinkler spacing for the ceiling level below. Skylights meeting this criteria are not restricted as to maximum depth or volume. When a sprinkler is located directly below a non-vented skylight recess (max. 32 s.f.), the allowable distance below the ceiling is measured from the main ceiling elevation, per 9.5.4.

Two common concerns include vented skylights and those with a plastic light transmitting material "cover". The vented skylight will vent hot gases and further delay sprinkler activation. Similarly, the plastic material may melt away and allow venting that delays sprinkler activation.

Unless vents comply with 20.9.5 for smoke and heat vents, with a higher activation temperature than the sprinkler, a sprinkler is required in the skylight recess. The highest elevation of the skylight is treated as the "ceiling" for purposes of locating the sprinkler below it. Skylights not exceeding 32 s.f. are permitted to have a plastic cover without a sprinkler in the skylight recess.

diagrams.title: Roof Skylight Insulation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Curbs for skylights are required to be insulated. The minimum R value for the curb is required to be either the continuous above deck value called for in table C402.1.3 or R-5 whichever is less. Curbs that are part of a NFRC 100 labeled skylight are not required to be insulated.

diagrams.title: Skylight Mounting (Non R-3 Occupancy)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Skylights are required to be mounted to curbs that are at least 4" tall. If the roofing assembly has a fire classification the plastic edges of the skylight dome must be protect by metal unless the dome can resist ignition when exposed to a flame from a Class B brand as described in ASTM E108 or UL 790. Curbs are not required for skylights at nonclassified roof coverings.

children.body: Vertical openings shall be permitted where allowed by other sections of this code.

diagrams.title: Exhaust System Outlets
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exhaust systems provide a way for air to be removed from a building. As outlined in the Mechanical Code, these mechanical exhaust systems include exhaust systems serving clothes dryers and cooking appliances; hazardous exhaust systems; dust, stock and refuse conveyor systems; subslab soil exhaust systems; smoke control systems; energy recovery ventilation systems and other systems specified in Section 502.
When the intake air or exhaust system is not properly designed, contaminated air has the possibility of entering the building which would reduce the indoor air quality and potentially cause unwanted odors or even potential health issues for the buildings occupants.

diagrams.title: Shaft Enclosure at the Top
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft extends to the underside of the roof sheathing, roof deck or roof assembly the top of the shaft may be enclosed by the roof required by the buildings construction type per table 601. Where the shaft terminates below the roof, the construction enclosing the top of the shaft must have a fire-resistance rating that is greater than or equal to both the fire-resistance rating of the shaft walls and the top floor penetrated by the shaft. Where the shaft extends above the roof assembly, the top of the enclosure is required to meet the requirement of Section 1511 for rooftop structures.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall at Secondary Member
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is one way of ensuring that a joint between an intermediate tube steel beam, such as might be found in a shaft, elevator shaft or stair enclosure could be treated to ensure protection of the steel member and continuity of the shaft wall. This assumes the member is a secondary framing member, and not a primary structural member framing into a column. The joints between the shaft wall and the other material is required to be detailed per the requirements for joint systems and an approved assembly be used. Source: hcai.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.08

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Design
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Hazardous exhaust systems must extend from the point of emissions capture to the building exterior without the potential to contaminate other building areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire area, to reach the building exterior, should be protected by shafts per building code section 713 or horizontal assemblies per section 711.2. This section specifically prohibits hazardous duct systems from extending into or through other duct or plenum systems to prevent contamination of environmental air systems.

children.body: The provisions of this section shall apply to shafts required to protect openings and penetrations through floor/ceiling and roof/ceiling assemblies. Interior exit stairways and ramps shall be enclosed in accordance with Section 1023.
Shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies in accordance with Section 711, or both.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

diagrams.title: Vertical Duct Shaft Bottom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is one example of the detailing of a shaft bottom with concrete and steel deck floor construction. The horizontal assembly requires an extra layer of gypsum board due to the fact that the heat from a fire would (initially) be more intense at the underside directly above a fire, than at the vertical face of the shaft. Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR4.02

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall at Secondary Member
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is one way of ensuring that a joint between an intermediate tube steel beam, such as might be found in a shaft, elevator shaft or stair enclosure could be treated to ensure protection of the steel member and continuity of the shaft wall. This assumes the member is a secondary framing member, and not a primary structural member framing into a column. The joints between the shaft wall and the other material is required to be detailed per the requirements for joint systems and an approved assembly be used. Source: hcai.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.08

children.body: Shaft enclosures shall be of materials permitted by the building type of construction.

Shaft enclosures shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 2 hours where connecting four stories or more, and not less than 1 hour where connecting less than four stories. The number of stories connected by the shaft enclosure shall include any basements but not any mezzanines. Shaft enclosures shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than the floor assembly penetrated, but need not exceed 2 hours. Shaft enclosures shall meet the requirements of Section 703.2.1.1.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

children.body: Shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both, and shall have continuity in accordance with Section 707.5 for fire barriers or Section 711.2.2 for horizontal assemblies, as applicable.

diagrams.title: Two Story Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In other than Groups I-2 and I-3, a vertical opening that is not used as one of the applications listed in Building Code Section 712.1, such as an atrium or escalator opening, is allowed. If an opening connecting stories is used for listed purposes, other requirements apply. If a two-story opening is used per 712.1.9, the opening must comply with all of the following items:
  1. Does not connect more than two stories.
  2. Does not penetrate a horizontal assembly that separates fire areas or smoke barriers that separate smoke compartments.
  3. Is not concealed within the construction of a wall or a floor/ceiling assembly.
  4. Is not open to a corridor in Group I and R occupancies.
  5. Is not open to a corridor on nonsprinklered floors.
  6. Is separated from floor openings and air transfer openings serving other floors by construction conforming to required shaft enclosures.

According to Section 713, shaft enclosures shall be constructed as fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.

children.body:
Where exterior walls serve as a part of a required shaft enclosure, such walls shall comply with the requirements of Section 705 for exterior walls and the fire-resistance-rated enclosure requirements shall not apply.
Exception: Exterior walls required to be fire-resistance rated in accordance with Section 1021.2 for exterior egress balconies, Section 1023.7 for interior exit stairways and ramps and Section 1027.6 for exterior exit stairways and ramps.

diagrams.title: Interior Stair & Ramp Exterior Wall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The exterior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures only need to meet the typical exterior wall requirements for the building based on its fire separation distance as defined in section 705. Where the exit stairway exterior wall is non-rated or has unprotected openings and the angle between the adjacent wall and the exterior wall of the exit stairway is less than 180 degrees, the first 10' of the immediately adjacent wall is required to have a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or more and 3/4 hour opening protection. The fire-rated wall and opening protection needs to be provided vertically from the ground up to 10' above the top floor landing or the roof line, whichever is lower. If the exterior wall of the exit stairway is rated and its openings are protected the wall immediately adjacent to the exit stairway may be constructed based on the fire separation distance per section 705.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection - Exception 2
