diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Ext. Stairway / Ramp Protection, Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior exit stairs and ramps are those that are open to "yards, courts, or public ways". These are not permitted for use in Group I-2 occupancy types, high rise buildings, or buildings exceeding six stories above grade plane. In all other buildings and occupancies they can serve as a required means of egress and must follow the installation and protection requirements of this section. In order to minimize the potential for accumulation of products of combustion, exterior exit stair must have one side open on each main and intermediate landing. To qualify as open, the area must have "not less than 35 sq. ft. of aggregate open area" at each floor level and intermediate landing; which must be "not less than 42 inches above" the floor or landing level. The exterior exit stair must have fire rated separation from the building interior in accordance with Section 1023.2. Several exceptions to fire separation from the building interior are shown.

diagrams.title: Ext. Stairway / Ramp Protection, Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior exit stairs and ramps are those that are open to "yards, courts, or public ways". These are not permitted for use in Group I-2 occupancy types, high rise buildings, or buildings exceeding six stories above grade plane. In all other buildings and occupancies they can serve as a required means of egress and must follow the installation and protection requirements of this section. In order to minimize the potential for accumulation of products of combustion, exterior exit stair must have one side open on each main and intermediate landing. To qualify as open, the area must have "not less than 35 sq. ft. of aggregate open area" at each floor level and intermediate landing; which must be "not less than 42 inches above" the floor or landing level. The exterior exit stair must have fire rated separation from the building interior in accordance with Section 1023.2. Several exceptions to fire separation from the building interior are shown.

children.body: Openings in a shaft enclosure shall be protected in accordance with Section 716 as required for fire barriers. Doors shall be self- or automatic-closing by smoke detection in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6.

children.body: Openings other than those necessary for the purpose of the shaft shall not be permitted in shaft enclosures.

Penetrations in a shaft enclosure shall be protected in accordance with Section 714 as required for fire barriers. Structural elements, such as beams or joists, where protected in accordance with Section 714 shall be permitted to penetrate a shaft enclosure.

Penetrations other than those necessary for the purpose of the shaft shall not be permitted in shaft enclosures.
Exception: Membrane penetrations shall be permitted on the outside of shaft enclosures. Such penetrations shall be protected in accordance with Section 714.4.2.
Joints in a shaft enclosure shall comply with Section 715.

diagrams.title: Example: Shaft Wall at Secondary Member
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The example shown is one way of ensuring that a joint between an intermediate tube steel beam, such as might be found in a shaft, elevator shaft or stair enclosure could be treated to ensure protection of the steel member and continuity of the shaft wall. This assumes the member is a secondary framing member, and not a primary structural member framing into a column. The joints between the shaft wall and the other material is required to be detailed per the requirements for joint systems and an approved assembly be used. Source: hcai.ca.gov. OPD No. FR3.08

children.body: Penetrations of a shaft enclosure by ducts and air transfer openings shall comply with Section 717.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Design
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Hazardous exhaust systems must extend from the point of emissions capture to the building exterior without the potential to contaminate other building areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire area, to reach the building exterior, should be protected by shafts per building code section 713 or horizontal assemblies per section 711.2. This section specifically prohibits hazardous duct systems from extending into or through other duct or plenum systems to prevent contamination of environmental air systems.

children.body:
Shafts that do not extend to the bottom of the building or structure shall comply with one of the following:
  1. Be enclosed at the lowest level with construction of the same fire-resistance rating as the lowest floor through which the shaft passes, but not less than the rating required for the shaft enclosure.
  2. Terminate in a room having a use related to the purpose of the shaft. The room shall be separated from the remainder of the building by fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. The fire-resistance rating and opening protectives shall be not less than the protection required for the shaft enclosure.
  3. Be protected by approved fire dampers installed in accordance with their listing at the lowest floor level within the shaft enclosure.
Exceptions:
  1. The fire-resistance-rated room separation is not required, provided that the only openings in or penetrations of the shaft enclosure to the interior of the building occur at the bottom. The bottom of the shaft shall be closed off around the penetrating items with materials permitted by Section 718.3.1 for draftstopping, or the room shall be provided with an approved automatic sprinkler system.
  2. A shaft enclosure containing a waste or linen chute shall not be used for any other purpose and shall discharge in a room protected in accordance with Section 713.13.4.
  3. The fire-resistance-rated room separation and the protection at the bottom of the shaft are not required provided that there are no combustibles in the shaft and there are no openings or other penetrations through the shaft enclosure to the interior of the building.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

diagrams.title: Shafts and Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Shaft enclosures and shaft bottoms are required to provide separation between the building and those shafts which communicate between floors. If for functionality a shaft is to open to the space below, like a laundry chute, then the rating requirement is broaded to include the room in which it opens to.

diagrams.title: Vertical Duct Shaft Bottom
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is one example of the detailing of a shaft bottom with concrete and steel deck floor construction. The horizontal assembly requires an extra layer of gypsum board due to the fact that the heat from a fire would (initially) be more intense at the underside directly above a fire, than at the vertical face of the shaft. Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No. FR4.02

children.body:
The top of shaft enclosures shall comply with one of the following:
  1. Extend to the underside of the roof sheathing, deck or slab of the building, and the roof assembly shall comply with the requirements for the type of construction as specified in Table 601.
  2. Terminate below the roof assembly and be enclosed at the top with construction of the same fire-resistance rating as the topmost floor penetrated by the shaft, but not less than the fire-resistance rating required for the shaft enclosure.
  3. Extend past the roof assembly and comply with the requirements of Section 1511.

diagrams.title: Shaft Enclosure at the Top
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft extends to the underside of the roof sheathing, roof deck or roof assembly the top of the shaft may be enclosed by the roof required by the buildings construction type per table 601. Where the shaft terminates below the roof, the construction enclosing the top of the shaft must have a fire-resistance rating that is greater than or equal to both the fire-resistance rating of the shaft walls and the top floor penetrated by the shaft. Where the shaft extends above the roof assembly, the top of the enclosure is required to meet the requirement of Section 1511 for rooftop structures.

children.body: A fire/smoke damper shall not be required at the penetration of the rooftop structure where shaft enclosures extend up through the roof assembly into a rooftop structure conforming to Section 1511. Ductwork in the shaft shall be connected directly to HVAC equipment.

Waste, recycling and linen chutes shall comply with the provisions of NFPA 82, Chapter 6 and shall meet the requirements of Sections 712 and 713.13.1 through 713.13.6. Incinerator rooms shall meet the provisions of Sections 713.13.4 and 713.13.5.
Exception: Chutes serving and contained within a single dwelling unit.

diagrams.title: Rubbish and Laundry Chutes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Waste, or rubbish, and linen chutes are required by the building code to be constructed of 1-hour fire rated materials and have equally rated, self or automatic closing, openings. Items can be inserted into the chutes from corridors or chute intake rooms. Chute intake rooms must be 1-hour fire rated with a minimum of 3/4 hour rated openings. Chute discharge or termination points, where the chute inserted items end, must be enclosed within a 1-hour fire rated room. Chutes are required to have a sprinkler head installed in the top of the chute, at every other floor, at the lowest level intake point, and in the discharge, or termination, room. For requirements for new construction, se building code (2018) Section 713.13.

children.displayTitle: 713.13 Waste, Recycling and Linen Chutes and Incinerator Rooms
children.titleText: Waste, Recycling and Linen Chutes and Incinerator Rooms

children.body: A shaft enclosure containing a recycling, waste or linen chute shall not be used for any other purpose and shall be enclosed in accordance with Section 713.4. A shaft enclosure shall be permitted to contain recycling and waste chutes. Openings into the shaft, from access rooms and discharge rooms, shall be protected in accordance with this section and Section 716. Openings into chutes shall not be located in corridors. Doors into chutes shall be self-closing. Discharge doors shall be self-or automatic-closing upon the actuation of a smoke detector in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6, except that heat-activated closing devices shall be permitted between the shaft and the discharge room.
children.displayTitle: 713.13.1 Waste, Recycling and Linen Chute Enclosures
children.titleText: Waste, Recycling and Linen Chute Enclosures

children.body: A shaft enclosure containing a waste, recycling, or linen chute shall be constructed of materials as permitted by the building type of construction.

Access openings for waste, recycling or linen chutes shall be located in rooms or compartments enclosed by not less than 1-hour fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. Openings into the access rooms shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. Doors shall be self- or automatic-closing upon the detection of smoke in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6. The room or compartment shall be configured to allow the access door to the room or compartment to close and latch with the access panel to the chute in any position.

Table 509.1Waste, recycling or linen chutes shall discharge into an enclosed room separated by fire barriers with a fire-resistance rating not less than the required fire rating of the shaft enclosure and constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. Openings into the discharge room from the remainder of the building shall be protected by opening protectives having a fire protection rating equal to the protection required for the shaft enclosure. Doors shall be self- or automatic-closing upon the detection of smoke in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6. Waste chutes shall not terminate in an incinerator room. Waste and linen rooms that are not provided with chutes need only comply with Table 509.1.
Incinerator rooms shall comply with Table 509.1.
An approved automatic sprinkler system shall be installed in accordance with Section 903.2.11.2.
Elevator, dumbwaiter and other hoistway enclosures shall be constructed in accordance with Sections 712 and 713, and Chapter 30.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit stairways and ramps are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit stairway and ramp or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists seven types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent fire exit stairway and ramps. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Prohibited Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit passageways are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit passageway or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists six types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent exit passageways. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 1
Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In California, this exception is only allowed in "...other than Group A, E, H, I, L and R occupancies, high-rise buildings, and other applications listed in Section 1.11 regulated by the Office of the State Fire Marshal. "

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Locations: Fire Partitions - Exception 1

children.body: The provisions of this section shall govern the materials and methods of construction used to protect through penetrations and membrane penetrations of horizontal assemblies and fire-resistance-rated wall assemblies.

Penetrations of fire-resistance-rated walls by ducts that are not protected with dampers shall comply with Sections 714.3 through 714.4.3. Penetrations of horizontal assemblies not protected with a shaft as permitted by Section 717.6, and not required to be protected with fire dampers by other sections of this code, shall comply with Sections 714.5 through 714.6.2. Ducts and air transfer openings that are protected with dampers shall comply with Section 717.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 1
Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In California, this exception is only allowed in "...other than Group A, E, H, I, L and R occupancies, high-rise buildings, and other applications listed in Section 1.11 regulated by the Office of the State Fire Marshal. "

children.body: A listed penetration firestop system shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and the listing criteria.

Where sleeves are used, they shall be securely fastened to the assembly penetrated. The space between the item contained in the sleeve and the sleeve itself and any space between the sleeve and the assembly penetrated shall be protected in accordance with this section. Insulation and coverings on or in the penetrating item shall not penetrate the assembly unless the specific material used has been tested as part of the assembly in accordance with this section.

Penetrations into or through fire walls, fire barriers, smoke barrier walls and fire partitions shall comply with Sections 714.4.1 through 714.4.3. Penetrations in smoke barrier walls shall also comply with Section 714.5.4.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: FIRE BARRIER. A fire-resistance-rated wall assembly of materials designed to restrict the spread of fire in which continuity is maintained.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers: Elevator Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

Sound-rated partitions are often used as smoke barriers because the assembly is specifically designed to resist the passage of air, which also transmits sound. When properly constructed with penetrations and joints treated to prevent air leakage, similar to the methods used for sound control, the partition can effectively prevent smoke passage as well.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partitions vs. Smoke Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE PARTITION. A wall assembly that extends from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above or to the underside of the ceiling above where the ceiling membrane is constructed to limit the transfer of smoke.
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

diagrams.title: Example: 1hr Recessed M.E.P. Cabinets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Items recessed in rated construction must maintain the rating of the wall they are in, and are considered a membrane penetration. This is an example of one method of maintaining protection at items such as panels or fire extinguisher boxes recessed into the wall. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. FR3.01

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

children.body:
Through penetrations of fire-resistance-rated walls shall comply with Section 714.4.1.1 or 714.4.1.2.
Exception: Where the penetrating items are steel, ferrous or copper pipes, tubes or conduits, the annular space between the penetrating item and the fire-resistance-rated wall is permitted to be protected by either of the following measures:
  1. In concrete or masonry walls where the penetrating item is a maximum 6-inch (152 mm) nominal diameter and the area of the opening through the wall does not exceed 144 square inches (0.0929 m2), concrete, grout or mortar is permitted where installed the full thickness of the wall or the thickness required to maintain the fire-resistance rating.
  2. The material used to fill the annular space shall prevent the passage of flame and hot gases sufficient to ignite cotton waste when subjected to ASTM E119 or UL 263 time-temperature fire conditions under a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch (2.49 Pa) of water at the location of the penetration for the time period equivalent to the fire-resistance rating of the construction penetrated.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Through Penetrations - Exceptions
diagrams.descriptionHtml: THROUGH-PENETRATION FIRESTOP SYSTEM.An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

children.body: Through penetrations shall be protected using systems installed as tested in the approved fire-resistance-rated assembly.

Through penetrations shall be protected by an approved penetration firestop system installed as tested in accordance with ASTM E814 or UL 1479, with a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch (2.49 Pa) of water and shall have an F rating of not less than the required fire-resistance rating of the wall penetrated.

Membrane penetrations shall comply with Section 714.4.1. Where walls or partitions are required to have a fire-resistance rating, recessed fixtures shall be installed such that the required fire resistance will not be reduced.
Exceptions:
  1. Membrane penetrations of maximum 2-hour fire-resistance-rated walls and partitions by steel electrical boxes that do not exceed 16 square inches (0.0 103 m2) in area, provided that the aggregate area of the openings through the membrane does not exceed 100 square inches (0.0645 m2) in any 100 square feet (9.29 m2) of wall area. The annular space between the wall membrane and the box shall not exceed 1/8 inch (3.2 mm). Such boxes on opposite sides of the wall or partition shall be separated by one of the following:
    1. By a horizontal distance of not less than 24 inches (610 mm) where the wall or partition is constructed with individual noncommunicating stud cavities.
    2. By a horizontal distance of not less than the depth of the wall cavity where the wall cavity is filled with cellulose loose-fill, rockwool or slag mineral wool insulation.
    3. By solid fireblocking in accordance with Section 718.2.1.
    4. By protecting both outlet boxes with listed putty pads.
    5. By other listed materials and methods.
  2. Membrane penetrations by listed electrical boxes of any material, provided that such boxes have been tested for use in fire-resistance-rated assemblies and are installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing. The annular space between the wall membrane and the box shall not exceed 1/8 inch (3.2 mm) unless listed otherwise. Such boxes on opposite sides of the wall or partition shall be separated by one of the following:
    1. By the horizontal distance specified in the listing of the electrical boxes.
    2. By solid fireblocking in accordance with Section 718.2.1.
    3. By protecting both boxes with listed putty pads.
    4. By other listed materials and methods.
  3. Membrane penetrations by electrical boxes of any size or type, that have been listed as part of a wall opening protective material system for use in fire-resistance-rated assemblies and are installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing.
  4. Membrane penetrations by boxes other than electrical boxes, provided that such penetrating items and the annular space between the wall membrane and the box, are protected by an approved membrane penetration firestop system installed as tested in accordance with ASTM E814 or UL 1479, with a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch (2.49 Pa) of water, and shall have an F and T rating of not less than the required fire-resistance rating of the wall penetrated and be installed in accordance with their listing.
  5. The annular space created by the penetration of an automatic sprinkler, provided that it is covered by a metal escutcheon plate.
  6. Membrane penetrations of maximum 2-hour fire-resistance-rated walls and partitions by steel electrical boxes that exceed 16 square inches (0.0 103 m2) in area, or steel electrical boxes of any size having an aggregate area through the membrane exceeding 100 square inches (0.0645 m2) in any 100 square feet (9.29 m2) of wall area, provided that such penetrating items are protected by listed putty pads or other listed materials and methods, and installed in accordance with the listing.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit stairways and ramps are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit stairway and ramp or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists seven types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent fire exit stairway and ramps. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Membrane Penetration Exception 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Membrane-Penetration Firestop:A material, device or construction installed to resist for a prescribed time period the passage of flame and heat through openings in a protective membrane in order to accommodate cables, cable trays, conduit, tubing, pipes or similar items.

diagrams.title: Example: 1hr Recessed M.E.P. Cabinets
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Items recessed in rated construction must maintain the rating of the wall they are in, and are considered a membrane penetration. This is an example of one method of maintaining protection at items such as panels or fire extinguisher boxes recessed into the wall. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD No. FR3.01

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Prohibited Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The enclosures for exit passageways are to protect occupants from fire and products of combustion like poisonous gas and smoke. As such, the code prohibits any penetrations that could compromise the safety of the enclosure to items specifically required by the exit passageway or its protection by emergency services by specifically defining what may penetrate the enclosure and lists six types of allowed penetrations. To further ensure the enclosure remains safe the code goes on to prohibit penetrations and communication openings between adjacent exit passageways. Single membrane penetrations of the exit stairway and ramp enclosures is only permitted to happen on the outside face of the enclosure and must be in accordance with section 714.4.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Membrane Penetrations: Electrical Boxes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Membrane-Penetration Firestop:A material, device or construction installed to resist for a prescribed time period the passage of flame and heat through openings in a protective membrane in order to accommodate cables, cable trays, conduit, tubing, pipes or similar items.

children.body: Noncombustible penetrating items shall not connect to combustible items beyond the point of firestopping unless it can be demonstrated that the fire-resistance integrity of the wall is maintained.

Penetrations of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor/ceiling assembly or the ceiling membrane of a roof/ceiling assembly not required to be enclosed in a shaft by Section 712.1 shall be protected in accordance with Sections 714.5.1 through 714.5.4.

diagrams.title: Vent Stack Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vent Stack: a vertical vent pipe installed primarily for the purpose of providing circulation of air to and from any part of the drainage system.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers: Elevator Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

Sound-rated partitions are often used as smoke barriers because the assembly is specifically designed to resist the passage of air, which also transmits sound. When properly constructed with penetrations and joints treated to prevent air leakage, similar to the methods used for sound control, the partition can effectively prevent smoke passage as well.

children.body:
Through penetrations of horizontal assemblies shall comply with Section 714.5.1.1 or 714.5.1.2.
Exceptions:
  1. Penetrations by steel, ferrous or copper conduits, pipes, tubes or vents or concrete or masonry items through a single fire-resistance-rated floor assembly where the annular space is protected with materials that prevent the passage of flame and hot gases sufficient to ignite cotton waste when subjected to ASTM E119 or UL 263 time-temperature fire conditions under a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch (2.49 Pa) of water at the location of the penetration for the time period equivalent to the fire-resistance rating of the construction penetrated. Penetrating items with a maximum 6-inch (152 mm) nominal diameter shall not be limited to the penetration of a single fire-resistance-rated floor assembly, provided that the aggregate area of the openings through the assembly does not exceed 144 square inches (92 900 mm2) in any 100 square feet (9.3 m2) of floor area.
  2. Penetrations in a single concrete floor by steel, ferrous or copper conduits, pipes, tubes or vents with a maximum 6-inch (152 mm) nominal diameter, provided that the concrete, grout or mortar is installed the full thickness of the floor or the thickness required to maintain the fire-resistance rating. The penetrating items shall not be limited to the penetration of a single concrete floor, provided that the area of the opening through each floor does not exceed 144 square inches (92 900 mm2).
  3. Penetrations by listed electrical boxes of any material, provided that such boxes have been tested for use in fire-resistance-rated assemblies and installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing.

diagrams.title: Horiz. Assy. Through Penetrations: Ex. 2 & 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Through-penetration firestop system:An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

diagrams.title: Horiz. Assy. Through Penetrations: Ex. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Through-penetration firestop system:An assemblage consisting of a fire-resistance-rated floor, floor-ceiling, or wall assembly, one or more penetrating items passing through the breaches in both sides of the assembly and the materials or devices, or both, installed to resist the spread of fire through the assembly for a prescribed period of time.

diagrams.title: Example: Water Closet Waste Line Slab Penetration
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This is one method of providing protection of a penetration for a fire-resistance rated floor assembly. Verify materials are compatible with code requirements and that the application is appropriate for your condition and accepted by your jurisdiction. Source: oshpd.ca.gov. OPD No: FR4.01

diagrams.title: Location of Vent Terminal (IPC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Vent terminals should be kept a minimum distance away from openings or air intake openings to prevent sewer gases from entering the building. Verify with the local jurisdiction about the required extension of the vent terminal above the roof.

children.body: Through penetrations shall be protected using systems installed as tested in the approved fire-resistance-rated assembly.

Through penetrations shall be protected by an approved through-penetration firestop system installed and tested in accordance with ASTM E814 or UL 1479, with a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch of water (2.49 Pa). The system shall have an F rating/T rating of not less than 1 hour but not less than the required rating of the floor penetrated.
Exceptions:
  1. Floor penetrations contained and located within the cavity of a wall above the floor or below the floor do not require a T rating.
  2. Floor penetrations by floor drains, tub drains or shower drains contained and located within the concealed space of a horizontal assembly do not require a T rating.
  3. Floor penetrations of maximum 4-inch (102 mm) nominal diameter metal conduit or tubing penetrating directly into metal-enclosed electrical power switchgear do not require a T rating.

Penetrations of membranes that are part of a horizontal assembly shall comply with Section 714.5.1.1 or 714.5.1.2. Where floor/ceiling assemblies are required to have a fire-resistance rating, recessed fixtures shall be installed such that the required fire resistance will not be reduced.
Exceptions:
  1. Membrane penetrations by steel, ferrous or copper conduits, pipes, tubes or vents, or concrete or masonry items where the annular space is protected either in accordance with Section 714.5.1 or to prevent the free passage of flame and the products of combustion. The aggregate area of the openings through the membrane shall not exceed 100 square inches (64 500 mm2) in any 100 square feet (9.3 m2) of ceiling area in assemblies tested without penetrations.
  2. Ceiling membrane penetrations of maximum 2-hour horizontal assemblies by steel electrical boxes that do not exceed 16 square inches (10 323 mm2) in area, provided that the aggregate area of such penetrations does not exceed 100 square inches (44 500 mm2) in any 100 square feet (9.29 m2) of ceiling area, and the annular space between the ceiling membrane and the box does not exceed 1/8 inch (3.2 mm).
  3. Membrane penetrations by electrical boxes of any size or type, that have been listed as part of an opening protective material system for use in horizontal assemblies and are installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing.
  4. Membrane penetrations by listed electrical boxes of any material, provided that such boxes have been tested for use in fire-resistance-rated assemblies and are installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing. The annular space between the ceiling membrane and the box shall not exceed 1/8 inch (3.2 mm) unless listed otherwise.
  5. The annular space created by the penetration of a fire sprinkler, provided that it is covered by a metal escutcheon plate.
  6. Noncombustible items that are cast into concrete building elements and that do not penetrate both top and bottom surfaces of the element.
  7. The ceiling membrane of a maximum 2-hour fire-resistance-rated horizontal assembly is permitted to be interrupted with the double wood top plate of a wall assembly that is sheathed with Type X gypsum wallboard, provided that all penetrating items through the double top plates are protected in accordance with Section 714.5.1.1 or 714.5.1.2 and the ceiling membrane is tight to the top plates.
  8. Ceiling membrane penetrations by listed luminaires (light fixtures) or by luminaires protected with listed materials, which have been tested for use in fire-resistance-rated assemblies and are installed in accordance with the instructions included in the listing.

diagrams.title: Fire Partition Continuity: Combustible Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In combustible construction where fire partitions do not extend to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above, the space above and along the line of the fire partition shall be provided with specific requirements.

It should be noted that per Section 714.5.2, the ceiling membrane of a maximum 2-hour fire-resistance-rated horizontal assembly is permitted to be interrupted with the double wood top plate of a wall assembly that is sheathed with Type X gypsum wallboard, provided that all penetrating items through the double top plates are protected in accordance with Section 714.5.1.1 or 714.5.1.2 and the ceiling membrane is tight to the top plates.

children.body: Noncombustible penetrating items shall not connect to combustible materials beyond the point of firestopping unless it can be demonstrated that the fire-resistance integrity of the horizontal assembly is maintained.

Penetrations in smoke barriers shall be protected by an approved through-penetration firestop system installed and tested in accordance with the requirements of UL 1479 for air leakage. The L rating of the system measured at 0.30 inch (7.47 Pa) of water in both the ambient temperature and elevated temperature tests shall not exceed either of the following:
  1. 5.0 cfm per square foot (0.025 m3/ s × m2) of penetration opening for each through-penetration firestop system.
  2. A total cumulative leakage of 50 cfm (0.024 m3/s) for any 100 square feet (9.3 m2) of wall area, or floor area.

Penetrations of nonfire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies or the ceiling membrane of a nonfire-resistance-rated roof/ceiling assembly shall meet the requirements of Section 713 or shall comply with Section 714.6.1 or 714.6.2.

Noncombustible penetrating items that connect not more than five stories are permitted, provided that the annular space is filled to resist the free passage of flame and the products of combustion with an approved noncombustible material or with a fill, void or cavity material that is tested and classified for use in through-penetration firestop systems.

Penetrating items that connect not more than two stories are permitted, provided that the annular space is filled with an approved material to resist the free passage of flame and the products of combustion.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

diagrams.title: Example: Metal Stud Wall Top / Steel Deck Firestopping
Interior Masonry Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Interior Masonry Partition / Metal Deck Firestopping

children.body: The provisions of this section shall govern the materials and methods of construction used to protect joints and voids in or between horizontal and vertical assemblies.

Systems or materials protecting joints and voids shall be securely installed in accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions in or on the joint or void for its entire length so as not to dislodge, loosen or otherwise impair its ability to accommodate expected building movements and to resist the passage of fire and hot gases. Fire-resistant joint systems or systems used to protect voids at exterior curtain walls and fire-resistance-rated floor intersections shall also be installed in accordance with the listing criteria.

Joints installed in or between fire-resistance-rated walls, floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and roofs or roof/ceiling assemblies shall be protected by an approved fire-resistant joint system designed to resist the passage of fire for a time period not less than the required fire-resistance rating of the wall, floor or roof in or between which the system is installed.
Exception: Fire-resistant joint systems shall not be required for joints in the following locations:
  1. Floors within a single dwelling unit.
  2. Floors where the joint is protected by a shaft enclosure in accordance with Section 713.
  3. Floors within atriums where the space adjacent to the atrium is included in the volume of the atrium for smoke control purposes.
  4. Floors within malls.
  5. Floors and ramps within parking garages or structures constructed in accordance with Sections 406.5 and 406.6.
  6. Mezzanine floors.
  7. Walls that are permitted to have unprotected openings.
  8. Roofs where openings are permitted.
  9. Control joints not exceeding a maximum width of 0.625 inch (15.9 mm) and tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263.
  10. The intersection of exterior curtain wall assemblies and the roof slab or roof deck.

diagrams.title: Example: Interior Metal Stud Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Example: Metal Stud Wall Top / Steel Deck Firestopping
Interior Masonry Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Interior Masonry Partition / Metal Deck Firestopping

children.body:
Fire-resistant joint systems shall be tested in accordance with the requirements of either ASTM E1966 or UL 2079. Nonsymmetrical wall joint systems shall be tested with both faces exposed to the furnace, and the assigned fire-resistance rating shall be the shortest duration obtained from the two tests. Where evidence is furnished to show that the wall was tested with the least fire-resistant side exposed to the furnace, subject to acceptance of the building official, the wall need not be subjected to tests from the opposite side.
Exception: For exterior walls with a horizontal fire separation distance greater than 10 feet (3048 mm), the joint system shall be required to be tested for interior fire exposure only.

Voids created at the intersection of exterior curtain wall assemblies and fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies shall be protected with an approved perimeter fire containment system to prevent the interior spread of fire. Such systems shall provide an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

diagrams.title: Side Clip Attachment: Bypass Wall Stud (Steel)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Proprietary or custom designed angles (clips) can be used to attach a metal stud bypassing the floor assembly. Bypass clips are used to attach exterior curtain wall studs to the building structure and provide either a rigid connection or deflecting connection for vertical building movement independent of the cold-formed steel framing.

Where curtain walls are extended on the outside of a spandrel member, a void can be created that could allow for the passage of smoke or flames. Special consideration of these conditions is required.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.body:
Perimeter fire containment systems shall be tested in accordance with the requirements of ASTM E2307.
Exception: Voids created at the intersection of the exterior curtain wall assemblies and floor assemblies where the vision glass extends to the finished floor level shall be permitted to be protected with an approved material to prevent the interior spread of fire. Such material shall be securely installed and capable of preventing the passage of flame and hot gases sufficient to ignite cotton waste where subjected to ASTM E119 time-temperature fire conditions under a minimum positive pressure differential of 0.01 inch (0.254 mm) of water column (2.5 Pa) for the time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor assembly.

Voids created at the intersection of exterior curtain wall assemblies and nonfire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies shall be filled with an approved material or system to retard the interior spread of fire and hot gases between stories.
children.displayTitle: 715.5 Exterior Curtain Wall/Nonfire-Resistance-Rated Floor Assembly Intersections
children.titleText: Exterior Curtain Wall/Nonfire-Resistance-Rated Floor Assembly Intersections

children.body: Voids created at the intersection of nonfire-resistance-rated exterior curtain wall assemblies and vertical fire barriers shall be filled with an approved material or system to retard the interior spread of fire and hot gases.
children.displayTitle: 715.6 Exterior Curtain Wall/Vertical Fire Barrier Intersections
children.titleText: Exterior Curtain Wall/Vertical Fire Barrier Intersections

children.body: Height and fire-resistance requirements for curtain wall spandrels shall comply with Section 705.8.5. Where Section 705.8.5 does not require fire-resistance-rated curtain wall spandrels, the requirements of Sections 715.4 and 715.5 shall still apply to the intersection between the curtain wall spandrels and the floor.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.body: Fire-resistant joint systems protecting joints in smoke barriers, and perimeter fire containment systems protecting voids at the intersection of a horizontal smoke barrier and an exterior curtain wall, shall be tested in accordance with the requirements of UL 2079 for air leakage. The L rating of the joint system shall not exceed 5 cubic feet per minute per linear foot (0.00775 m3/s m) of joint at 0.30 inch (74.7 Pa) of water for both the ambient temperature and elevated temperature tests.

diagrams.title: Smoke Barriers: Elevator Enclosures
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

Sound-rated partitions are often used as smoke barriers because the assembly is specifically designed to resist the passage of air, which also transmits sound. When properly constructed with penetrations and joints treated to prevent air leakage, similar to the methods used for sound control, the partition can effectively prevent smoke passage as well.

diagrams.title: Voids at Curtain Wall Intersections
diagrams.descriptionHtml: To prevent the interior spread of fire the code requires that the void between a fire-resistance-rated floor or floor/ceiling assemblies and an exterior curtain wall needs to be filled with an approved perimeter fire containment system. The perimeter fire containment system is required to have an F rating for a time period not less than the fire-resistance rating of the floor or floor/ceiling assembly.

children.displayTitle: 715.8 Joints and Voids in Smoke Barriers
children.titleText: Joints and Voids in Smoke Barriers

diagrams.title: Interior Stair & Ramp Exterior Wall Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The exterior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures only need to meet the typical exterior wall requirements for the building based on its fire separation distance as defined in section 705. Where the exit stairway exterior wall is non-rated or has unprotected openings and the angle between the adjacent wall and the exterior wall of the exit stairway is less than 180 degrees, the first 10' of the immediately adjacent wall is required to have a fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or more and 3/4 hour opening protection. The fire-rated wall and opening protection needs to be provided vertically from the ground up to 10' above the top floor landing or the roof line, whichever is lower. If the exterior wall of the exit stairway is rated and its openings are protected the wall immediately adjacent to the exit stairway may be constructed based on the fire separation distance per section 705.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stair w/ Exit Passageway: Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When an interior exit stairway or ramp cannot provide direct access to an exit discharge or public way, the code permits the use of an exit passageway to extend the interior exit stairway or ramp to facilitate such access. Exit passageways' enclosures, which encompass walls, floors, and ceilings, are mandated to be constructed as fire-barriers. They must possess a fire-resistance of either 1-hour or the fire-resistance requisite for any connected interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure, opting for whichever specification is greater. For reference, a typical exit stairway enclosure has a 2-hour fire-resistance rating.

The interior exit stairway or ramp must be separated from the exit passageway by a fire barrier, which should carry a fire-resistance rating not less than that of the interior exit stairway or ramp enclosure. In order to access the exit passageway from the exit stairway or ramp, a fire door, compliant with Section 716, must be incorporated into the fire barrier, which establishes separation between the exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway. Any openings and penetrations in the fire barrier that segregates the exit stairway or ramp from the passageway—apart from the fire door intended to provide exit from the stairway or ramp—are prohibited.

However, the code does provide allowance for incidental penetrations of the fire barrier, required for construction and life safety elements related to ventilation, fire protection, security, and communications systems, in addition to electrical raceways serving fire communications and the exit stairway or ramp, and for structural elements sustaining the stairway or ramp. All penetrations must be safeguarded in accordance with Section 714.

Moreover, the fire barrier and fire door, positioned between the exit passageway and the exit stairway or ramp, may be omitted under specific circumstances: where there are no openings into the exit passageway or where the interior exit stairway or ramp and the exit passageway are pressurized in line with Section 909.20.5.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.4 defines the type of wall openings that may be placed in interior exit stair walls. The only openings allowed in interior walls of interior exit stairway enclosures are exit doors that provide access to the stairway enclosure from normally occupied spaces and for exiting from the enclosure. Since interior exit stairways need to be separated from the rest of the building by vertical fire barriers (707) or a rated horizontal assembly (711), section 1023.4 also requires any openings in the interior walls to be protected in accordance with section 716. The actual level of opening protection required is established by table 716.1(2) which defines the rating/level of protection of any openings between an interior space and the exit stairway. 1023.4 further clarifies that elevators may not open into interior exit stairway enclosures.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Exit Passageways: Ventilation Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1024.7 is to ensure that the environment within exit passageways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Passageway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The passageway ventilation system(s) must be completely separate from the building ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with Section 716.

diagrams.title: Interior Exit Stairways: Ventilation
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1023.6 is to ensure that the environment within exit stairways does not become contaminated and prevent occupants from exiting in the event of an emergency. Stairway intake and exhaust air must be directly from the exterior of the building. Any equipment and ductwork outside of the passageway must be separated from the remainder of the building by shaft construction, which calls for fire barriers. The stairway ventilation system(s) must be completely separated from the buildings ventilation system(s). Openings through the rated equipment enclosure are limited to those needed for maintenance and operation and must be protected in accordance with section 716.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Buildings on Same Lot: Vertical Exposure
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Buildings on the same lot but that are of different heights may require protection of the upper windows against fire that could be coming from a fire at the adjacent lower building. This code section does not address a requirement for the wall itself to be fire rated, but the opening to have protection. Table 602 would govern the required fire rating based on the fire-separation distance. However, if the wall between the buildings is a fire wall, then 706.6.1 would apply, which requires a fire rating of the 15 feet that extend beyond the lower building.

diagrams.title: Example: Hollow Metal Jamb - 2hr Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated assemblies at hollow metal door jambs should be detailed to maintain the fire rating at the interface of the door jamb and a 2-hr wall assembly. This is one example of how this can be accomplished. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD NO. FR3.03

diagrams.title: Example: Hollow Metal Jamb - 1hr Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated assemblies at hollow metal door jambs should be detailed to maintain the fire rating at the interface of the door jamb and a 1-hr wall assembly. This is one example of how this can be accomplished. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD NO. FR3.02

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

diagrams.title: Vertical Offsets in Podium Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a vertical offset is part of a horizontal assembly utilized to establish separate buildings the offset is required to be constructed as a 3 hour minimum fire-resistance rated fire barrier per Section 707. Structural elements that support the fire-barrier need protection equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier being supported.

diagrams.title: Enclosure of Atriums: Exception 2 - Glass Block Partition
Corridor doors in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In a group I-2 occupancy, doors in corridor walls not required to provide fire separation from incidental uses, vertical openings (shafts), or exits are not required to have a fire protection rating or to have self/automatic-closing devices. They must, however, provide an effective smoke barrier and be equipped with positive latching lockset (roller latches not permitted). Where the corridor wall is required to be rated the door openings are required to be protected in accordance with Table 716.1(2).

diagrams.title: Smoke Activated Door Closers and Hold-Opens
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire doors that are required to close automatically may be held open by a hold-open device. The hold-open device is required to released the door when any of the following conditions occur:
  1. Smoke detectors are activated
  2. Loss of power to the smoke detector occurs
  3. Loss of power to the hold-open device occurs

children.body: Opening protectives required by other sections of this code shall comply with the provisions of this section and shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 80.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft)- 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. (Reserved)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is not required for sprinklered low-rise buildings (i.e., highest occupied floor is <75 feet above lowest level of fire department vehicular access) (§3006.2)
  10. (Reserved)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2).
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. (Reserved)
  18. (Reserved)
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory.
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Nonsprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby, is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), 1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless (a)the shaft is pressurized, or (b)smoke-stop doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors) (§716.2.2.1.1). This applies for all rated corridors, even if smoke protection for the elevator shaft is not required per §3006.2. (Table 1020.2 + Table 716.1(2) + 716.2.2.1) (If the elevator connects 4 or more floors, the enclosed elevator lobby is also required per §3006.2, except at the level of exit discharge.)

  13. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 + §1020.2)
  14. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (1020.7 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  15. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 Exception 1 + §1020.2)
