  17. Any enclosed elevator lobby bisecting a rated corridor requires 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2).
  18. Corridor doors at an enclosed elevator lobby must be 20-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1)

children.body:
The application of any of the alternative methods specified in this section shall be based on the fire exposure and acceptance criteria specified in NFPA 252, NFPA 257, UL 9, UL 10B or UL 10C. The required fire resistance of an opening protective shall be permitted to be established by any of the following methods or procedures:
  1. Designs documented in approved sources.
  2. Calculations performed in an approved manner.
  3. Engineering analysis based on a comparison of opening protective designs having fire protection ratings as determined by the test procedures set forth in NFPA 252, NFPA 257, UL 9, UL 10B or UL 10C.
  4. Alternative protection methods as allowed by Section 104.11.
children.displayTitle: 716.1.1 Alternative Methods for Determining Fire Protection Ratings
children.titleText: Alternative Methods for Determining Fire Protection Ratings

children.body: Glazing used in fire door assemblies and fire window assemblies shall comply with this section in addition to the requirements of Sections 716.2 and 716.3, respectively.

Fire-protection-rated glazing and fire-resistance-rated glazing installed in fire door assemblies and fire window assemblies shall comply with the safety glazing requirements of Chapter 24 where applicable.

diagrams.title: Glazing In / Adjacent to Doors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing in or adjacent to doors shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Glazing: Hazardous Locations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A set of conditions denote a hazardous location for glazing in either fixed or operable panels. These conditions specify that the exposed area of an individual pane must be greater than 9 square feet. The glazing panel is also expected to be positioned in a manner where the bottom edge is less than 18 inches above the floor and the top edge is greater than 36 inches above the floor. Another significant factor requires that one or more walking surfaces are placed within 36 inches, measured horizontally and in a straight line, of the plane of the glazing. The regulation identifies such scenarios as potentially hazardous due to the risk they might pose to the safety of inhabitants or users.

Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

diagrams.title: Glazing Next to Stairs, Ramps
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Glazing adjacent to stairs and ramps shall be considered to be in a hazardous location and required safety glazing materials. Safety glazing materials, including but not limited to tempered glass, laminated glass, wire glass or rigid plastic, are used in hazardous locations where the potential for human impact can lead to serious injuries.

children.body: Fire-rated glazing assemblies shall be marked in accordance with Tables 716.1(1), 716.1(2) and 716.1(3).

For fire-rated glazing, the label shall bear the identification required in Tables 716.1(1) and 716.1(2). "D" indicates that the glazing is permitted to be used in fire door assemblies and meets the fire protection requirements of NFPA 252, UL 10B or UL 10C. "H" indicates that the glazing meets the hose stream requirements of NFPA 252, UL 10B or UL 10C. "T" indicates that the glazing meets the temperature requirements of Section 716.2.2.3.1. The placeholder "XXX" represents the fire-rating period, in minutes.

For fire-protection-rated glazing, the label shall bear the following identification required in Tables 716.1(1) and 716.1(3): "OH - XXX." "OH" indicates that the glazing meets both the fire protection and the hose-stream requirements of NFPA 257 or UL 9 and is permitted to be used in fire window openings. The placeholder "XXX" represents the fire-rating period, in minutes.
For fire-resistance-rated glazing, the label shall bear the identification required in Section 703.4 and Table 716.1(1).

Fire-rated glazing assemblies marked as complying with hose stream requirements (H) shall be permitted in applications that do not require compliance with hose stream requirements. Fire-rated glazing assemblies marked as complying with temperature rise requirements (T) shall be permitted in applications that do not require compliance with temperature rise requirements. Fire-rated glazing assemblies marked with ratings (XXX) that exceed the ratings required by this code shall be permitted.
children.displayTitle: 716.1.2.2.4 Fire-Rated Glazing That Exceeds the Code Requirements
children.titleText: Fire-Rated Glazing That Exceeds the Code Requirements

children.body: Fire-resistance-rated glazing tested as part of a fire-resistance-rated wall or floor/ceiling assembly in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 and labeled in accordance with Section 703.4 shall not otherwise be required to comply with this section where used as part of a wall or floor/ceiling assembly.

Fire-resistance-rated glazing shall be permitted in fire door and fire window assemblies where tested and installed in accordance with their listings and where in compliance with the requirements of this section.
children.displayTitle: 716.1.2.3.1 Glazing in Fire Door and Fire Window Assemblies
children.titleText: Glazing in Fire Door and Fire Window Assemblies

children.body: Fire door assemblies required by other sections of this code shall comply with the provisions of this section. Fire door frames with transom lights, sidelights or both shall be permitted in accordance with Section 716.2.5.4.

diagrams.title: Corridor doors in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In a group I-2 occupancy, doors in corridor walls not required to provide fire separation from incidental uses, vertical openings (shafts), or exits are not required to have a fire protection rating or to have self/automatic-closing devices. They must, however, provide an effective smoke barrier and be equipped with positive latching lockset (roller latches not permitted). Where the corridor wall is required to be rated the door openings are required to be protected in accordance with Table 716.1(2).

children.body:
Approved fire door and fire shutter assemblies shall be constructed of any material or assembly of component materials that conforms to the test requirements of Sections 716.2.1.1 through 716.2.1.4 and the fire protection rating indicated in Table 716.1(2).
Exceptions:
  1. Labeled protective assemblies that conform to the requirements of this section or UL 10A, UL 14B and UL 14C for tin-clad fire door assemblies.
  2. Floor fire door assemblies in accordance with Section 712.1.13.1.

Fire door assemblies with side-hinged and pivoted swinging doors shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 252 or UL 10C. For tests conducted in accordance with NFPA 252, the fire test shall be conducted using the positive pressure method specified in the standard.

Fire door assemblies with other types of doors, including swinging elevator doors, horizontal sliding fire doors, rolling steel fire doors, fire shutters, bottom- and side-hinged chute intake doors, and top-hinged chute discharge doors, shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 252 or UL 10B. For tests conducted in accordance with NFPA 252, the neutral pressure plane in the furnace shall be maintained as nearly equal to the atmospheric pressure as possible at the top of the door, as specified in the standard.

Glazing material in any other part of the door assembly, including transom lights and sidelights, shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 257 or UL 9, including the hose stream test, in accordance with Section 716.3.1.1.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.1.3 Glazing in Transoms Lights and Sidelights in Corridors and Smoke Barriers
children.titleText: Glazing in Transoms Lights and Sidelights in Corridors and Smoke Barriers

children.body: Fire door assemblies that serve as smoke and draft control assemblies shall be tested in accordance with UL 1784.
Fire door assemblies shall be installed in the assemblies specified in Table 716.1(2) and shall comply with the fire protection rating specified.

diagrams.title: Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies

children.body:
Fire door assemblies required to have a minimum fire protection rating of 20 minutes where located in corridor walls or smoke barrier walls having a fire-resistance rating in accordance with Table 716.1(2) shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 252 or UL 10C without the hose stream test.
Exceptions:
  1. Viewports that require a hole not larger than 1 inch (25 mm) in diameter through the door, have not less than a 0.25-inch-thick (6.4 mm) glass disc and the holder is of metal that will not melt out where subject to temperatures of 1,700°F (927°C).
  2. Corridor door assemblies in occupancies of Group I-2 shall be in accordance with Section 407.3.1.
  3. Unprotected openings shall be permitted for corridors in multitheater complexes where each motion picture auditorium has not fewer than one-half of its required exit or exit access doorways opening directly to the exterior or into an exit passageway.
  4. Horizontal sliding doors in smoke barriers that comply with Sections 408.6 and 408.8.4 in occupancies in Group I-3.

diagrams.title: Fire Service Elev: Smoke Proof Enclosure
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Service Access Elevators (FSAE) provide a protected means by which firefighters can access occupied building floors more than 120 feet above the lowest level of fire apparatus access. When FSAE are required by 403.6.1, they need to meet the requirements of 3007, including provision for a lobby meeting 3007.6. Lobbies for FSAE must meet specified criteria, including:
  • Lobby is not required for FSAE opening at level of exit discharge
  • FSAE Lobby must have direct access to an interior exit stairway/ramp or by way of an approved path, constructed consistent with requirements of FSAE lobby
  • FSAE lobby must be enclosed by 1-hour smoke barrier
  • FSAE lobby doorways must have minimum 3/4 hour rating meeting smoke/draft control requirements of 716.2.2.1.1
  • 3/4 hour fire door(s) / smoke and draft control assembly(ies)
  • FSAE lobby must be minimum 150 square feet with least dimension not less than 8 feet

NOTE: Stairs or ramps serving floors more than 75 feet above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access shall be a smokeproof enclosure per 403.5.4, designed in accordance with 909.20. Where 3007.6.1 requires direct access from the FSAE to an interior exit stairway or ramp, this should be taken to mean direct access to the smokeproof enclosure that includes the stairway or ramp, such that the FSAE lobby does not compromise the integrity of the smokeproof enclosure. It would be acceptable to have the FSAE lobby directly access a open exterior balcony, ventilated vestibule or pressurized entrance vestibule that provides access to the pressurized stair, as established in 909.20.

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations: Corridors - Item 3
Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Nonsprinklered, 0-75 ft) - 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7)
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1)
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby, is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), 1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed elevator lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless (a)the shaft is pressurized, or (b)smoke-stop doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors) (§716.2.2.1.1). This applies for all rated corridors, even if smoke protection for the elevator shaft is not required per §3006.2. (Table 1020.2 + Table 716.1(2) + 716.2.2.1) (If the elevator connects 4 or more floors, the enclosed elevator lobby is also required per §3006.2, except at the level of exit discharge.)
  10. At least one exit without passing through the enclosed elevator lobby.(§1016.2(1)
  11. Corridors require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2)
  12. Corridors require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke)rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  13. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 + §1020.2)
  14. Unenclosed exit access stairs or ramps serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (1020.7 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  15. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.7 Exception 1 + §1020.2)
  16. Foyers, lobbies, or reception rooms serving a rated corridor require 20-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (§1020.7 Exception 1 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1).
  17. Any enclosed elevator lobby bisecting a rated corridor requires 1-hour fire partitions (§1020.2).
  18. Corridor doors at an enclosed elevator lobby must be 20-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1).
  19. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Shafts connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§713.4). In Type I construction, 2-hour fire barriers are required in all cases (§713.4 + Table 601).
  20. Elevator shafts connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute automatic-closing smoke-activated fire doors. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §713.7 + §716.2.6.6). An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), but the mitigation described in Note 9 is mandatory
  21. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 1-hour fire barriers. Stair enclosures connecting 4 or more stories require 2-hour fire barriers (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways connecting 1-3 stories require 60-minute self closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) rating. For shafts connecting 4 or more stories, 90-minute doors are required (Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, §716.2.2.1.1)

children.displayTitle: 716.2.2.1 Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers
children.titleText: Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers

children.body: The air leakage rate of the door assembly shall not exceed 3.0 cubic feet per minute per square foot (0.01524 m3/s × m2) of door opening at 0.10 inch (24.9 Pa) of water for both the ambient temperature and elevated temperature tests. Louvers shall be prohibited. Terminated stops shall be prohibited on doors required by Section 405.4.3 to comply with Section 716.2.2.1 and prohibited on doors required by Item 3 of Section 3006.3, or Section 3007.6.3 or 3008.6.3 to comply with this section.

diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

children.body: Fire door assemblies required to have a minimum fire protection rating of 20 minutes where located in other fire partitions having a fire-resistance rating of 0.5 hour in accordance with Table 716.1(2) shall be tested in accordance with NFPA 252, UL 10B or UL 10C with the hose stream test.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.2.2 Door Assemblies in Other Fire Partitions
children.titleText: Door Assemblies in Other Fire Partitions

children.body:
Fire door assemblies in interior exit stairways and ramps and exit passageways shall have a maximum transmitted temperature rise of not more than 450°F (250°C) above ambient at the end of 30 minutes of standard fire test exposure.
Exception: The maximum transmitted temperature rise is not required in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.displayTitle: 716.2.2.3 Doors in Interior Exit Stairways and Ramps and Exit Passageways
children.titleText: Doors in Interior Exit Stairways and Ramps and Exit Passageways

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing in excess of 100 square inches (0.065 m2) is not permitted. Fire-resistance-rated glazing in excess of 100 square inches (0.065 m2) shall be permitted in fire doors. Listed fire-resistance-rated glazing in a fire door shall have a maximum transmitted temperature rise in accordance with Section 716.2.2.3 when the fire door is tested in accordance with NFPA 252, UL 10B or UL 10C.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Fire doors installed within a fire door assembly shall meet the fire rating indicated in Table 716.1(2).
Fire door frames installed as part of a fire door assembly shall meet the fire rating indicated in Table 716.1(2).

diagrams.title: Example: Hollow Metal Jamb - 2hr Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated assemblies at hollow metal door jambs should be detailed to maintain the fire rating at the interface of the door jamb and a 2-hr wall assembly. This is one example of how this can be accomplished. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD NO. FR3.03

diagrams.title: Example: Hollow Metal Jamb - 1hr Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated assemblies at hollow metal door jambs should be detailed to maintain the fire rating at the interface of the door jamb and a 1-hr wall assembly. This is one example of how this can be accomplished. Source: OSHPD.CA.GOV. OPD NO. FR3.02

children.body: Fire-rated glazing conforming to the opening protection requirements in Section 716.2.1 shall be permitted in fire door assemblies.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Fire-resistance-rated glazing shall comply with the size limitations in Section 716.2.5.1.1. Fire-protection-rated glazing shall comply with the size limitations of NFPA 80, and as provided in Section 716.2.5.1.2.

Fire-resistance-rated glazing tested to ASTM E119 or UL 263 and NFPA 252, UL 10B or UL 10C shall be permitted in fire door assemblies located in fire walls and in fire barriers in accordance with Table 716.1(2) to the maximum size tested and in accordance with their listings.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.5.1.1 Fire-Resistance-Rated Glazing in Door Assemblies in Fire Walls and Fire Barriers Rated Greater Than 1 Hour
children.titleText: Fire-Resistance-Rated Glazing in Door Assemblies in Fire Walls and Fire Barriers Rated Greater Than 1 Hour

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be prohibited in fire walls and fire barriers except as provided in Sections 716.2.5.1.2.1 and 716.2.5.1.2.2.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.5.1.2 Fire-Protection-Rated Glazing in Door Assemblies in Fire Walls and Fire Barriers Rated Greater Than 1 Hour
children.titleText: Fire-Protection-Rated Glazing in Door Assemblies in Fire Walls and Fire Barriers Rated Greater Than 1 Hour

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be permitted as vision panels in self-closing swinging fire door assemblies serving as horizontal exits in fire walls where limited to 100 square inches (0.065 m2).

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A horizontal exit compartmentalizes a building allowing occupants to exit the area containing the origin of a fire into another portion of the building that is protected by fire-resistance-rated assemblies (doors, walls, ceilings, and floors). A horizontal exit separates a space into two exit access areas. Code requirements for horizontal exits address fire-rated separation, opening protectives, capacity, and other features.

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be permitted in fire doors having a 11/2-hour fire protection rating intended for installation in fire barriers, where limited to 100 square inches (0.065 m2).

Approved fire-protection-rated glazing used in fire door assemblies in elevator, stairway and ramp enclosures shall be so located as to furnish clear vision of the passageway or approach to the elevator, stairway or ramp.
In a 20-minute fire door assembly, the glazing material in the door itself shall have a minimum fire-protection-rated glazing of 20 minutes and shall be exempt from the hose stream test.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.5.3 Glazing in Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers
children.titleText: Glazing in Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be permitted in door frames with transom lights, sidelights or both, where a 3/4-hour fire protection rating or less is required and in 2-hour fire-resistance-rated exterior walls in accordance with Table 716.1(2). Fire door frames with transom lights, sidelights or both, installed with fire-resistance-rated glazing tested as an assembly in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall be permitted where a fire protection rating exceeding 3/4 hour is required in accordance with Table 716.1(2).
children.displayTitle: 716.2.5.4 Fire Door Frames With Transom Lights and Sidelights
children.titleText: Fire Door Frames With Transom Lights and Sidelights

children.body: Fire-protection-rated glazing shall not be permitted in fire door frames with transom lights and sidelights in fire barriers required by Section 1207 of the International Fire Code to enclose energy storage systems.
Fire door hardware and closures shall be installed on fire door assemblies in accordance with the requirements of this section.

diagrams.title: Smoke Activated Door Closers and Hold-Opens
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire doors that are required to close automatically may be held open by a hold-open device. The hold-open device is required to released the door when any of the following conditions occur:
  1. Smoke detectors are activated
  2. Loss of power to the smoke detector occurs
  3. Loss of power to the hold-open device occurs

diagrams.title: Door Hardware Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code defines acceptable hardware mounting heights for that are a part of the means of egress. Handles, pulls, latches locks other operating devices are required to be from 34" minimum to 48" maximum above the finish floor. Locks used only for security purposes may be at any height provided the lock is not used for normal operation of the door. The code makes an exception for doors and gates that are part of a barrier for pools, spas or hot tubs, which may have the latch release for the self-latching device not more than 54" above the finish floor.

children.body:
Fire doors shall be latching and self- or automatic-closing in accordance with this section.
Exceptions:
  1. Fire doors located in common walls separating sleeping units in Group R-1 shall be permitted without automatic- or self-closing devices.
  2. The elevator car doors and the associated hoistway enclosure doors at the floor level designated for recall in accordance with Section 3003.2 shall be permitted to remain open during Phase I emergency recall operation.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft)- 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

children.body: Unless otherwise specifically permitted, single side-hinged swinging fire doors and both leaves of pairs of side-hinged swinging fire doors shall be provided with an active latch bolt that will secure the door when it is closed.
Chute intake doors shall be positive latching, remaining latched and closed in the event of latch spring failure during a fire emergency.
Automatic-closing fire door assemblies shall be self-closing in accordance with NFPA 80.
Doors required to be self-closing and not required to be automatic closing shall be permitted to be equipped with delayed-action closers.

Automatic-closing doors installed in the following locations shall be permitted to have hold-open devices. Doors shall automatically close by the actuation of smoke detectors installed in accordance with Section 907.3 or by loss of power to the smoke detector or hold-open device. Doors that are automatic-closing by smoke detection shall not have more than a 10-second delay before the door starts to close after the smoke detector is actuated. Automatic-closing doors that protect openings installed in the following locations shall comply with this section:
  1. In walls that separate incidental uses in accordance with Section 509.4.
  2. In fire walls in accordance with Section 706.8.
  3. In fire barriers in accordance with Section 707.6.
  4. In fire partitions in accordance with Section 708.6.
  5. In smoke barriers in accordance with Section 709.5.
  6. In smoke partitions in accordance with Section 710.5.2.3.
  7. In shaft enclosures in accordance with Section 713.7.
  8. In waste and linen chutes, discharge openings and access and discharge rooms in accordance with Section 713.13. Loading doors installed in waste and linen chutes shall meet the requirements of Sections 716.2.6.1 and 716.2.6.3.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The purpose of smoke partitions is to restrict the movement of smoke within a building by forming a continuous membrane extending from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck, or slab above or the underside of the ceiling above (Section 710.4). They are designed to limit the free passage of smoke and are required to have specific materials, openings, and penetrations that meet established standards in order to prevent smoke from spreading throughout the building (710.2, 710.5, 710.6). Smoke partitions are not required to have a fire-resistance rating unless required elsewhere in the code (710.3).

diagrams.title: Smoke Activated Door Closers and Hold-Opens
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire doors that are required to close automatically may be held open by a hold-open device. The hold-open device is required to released the door when any of the following conditions occur:
  1. Smoke detectors are activated
  2. Loss of power to the smoke detector occurs
  3. Loss of power to the hold-open device occurs

children.body: Vertical sliding or vertical rolling steel fire doors in openings through which pedestrians travel shall be heat activated or activated by smoke detectors with alarm verification.

Where fire shutters of the swinging type are installed in exterior openings, not less than one row in every three vertical rows shall be arranged to be readily opened from the outside, and shall be identified by distinguishing marks or letters not less than 6 inches (152 mm) high.
Where fire shutters of the rolling type are installed, such shutters shall include approved automatic-closing devices.
Fire door assemblies shall be labeled by an approved agency. The labels shall comply with NFPA 80, and shall be permanently affixed to the door or frame.

children.body: Fire doors shall be labeled showing the name of the manufacturer or other identification readily traceable back to the manufacturer, the name or trademark of the third-party inspection agency, the fire protection rating and, where required for fire doors in interior exit stairways and ramps and exit passageways by Section 716.2.2.3, the maximum transmitted temperature end point. Smoke and draft control doors complying with UL 1784 shall be labeled as such and shall comply with Section 716.2.9.3. Labels shall be approved and permanently affixed. The label shall be applied at the factory or location where fabrication and assembly are performed.

Listed light kits and louvers and their required preparations shall be considered as part of the labeled door where such installations are done under the listing program of the third-party agency. Fire doors and fire door assemblies shall be permitted to consist of components, including glazing, vision light kits and hardware that are listed or classified and labeled for such use by different third-party agencies.

Oversized fire doors shall bear an oversized fire door label by an approved agency or shall be provided with a certificate of inspection furnished by an approved testing agency. Where a certificate of inspection is furnished by an approved testing agency, the certificate shall state that the door conforms to the requirements of design, materials and construction, but has not been subjected to the fire test.

Smoke and draft control doors complying with UL 1784 shall be labeled in accordance with Section 716.2.9.1 and shall show the letter "S" on the fire-rating label of the door. This marking shall indicate that the door and frame assembly are in compliance where listed or labeled gasketing is installed.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.9.3 Smoke and Draft Control Door Labeling Requirements
children.titleText: Smoke and Draft Control Door Labeling Requirements

children.body: Fire door frames shall be labeled showing the names of the manufacturer and the third-party inspection agency.

Fire-rated glazing shall bear a label or other identification showing the name of the manufacturer, the test standard and information required in Table 716.1(1) that shall be issued by an approved agency and shall be permanently identified on the glazing.
Fire door operators for horizontal sliding doors shall be labeled and listed for use with the assembly.
Installation of smoke doors shall be in accordance with NFPA 105.
children.displayTitle: 716.2.10 Installation of Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers
children.titleText: Installation of Door Assemblies in Corridors and Smoke Barriers

children.body: Fire window assemblies required by other sections of this code shall comply with the provisions of this section.

Fire window assemblies shall be constructed of any material or assembly of component materials that conforms to the test requirements of Sections 716.3.1.1 and 716.3.1.2 and the fire protection rating indicated in Table 716.1(3).

NFPA 257 or UL 9 shall evaluate                     fire-protection-rated glazing under positive pressure. Within the first 10                     minutes of a test, the pressure in the furnace shall be adjusted so not less                     than two-thirds of the test specimen is above the neutral pressure plane, and                     the neutral pressure plane shall be maintained at that height for the balance of                     the test.

Nonsymmetrical fire-protection-rated glazing systems in fire partitions, fire barriers or in exterior walls with a fire separation distance of 10 feet (3048 mm) or less pursuant to Section 705 shall be tested with both faces exposed to the furnace, and the assigned fire protection rating shall be the shortest duration obtained from the two tests conducted in compliance with NFPA 257 or UL 9.
Fire window assemblies shall be installed in the assemblies and comply with the fire protection rating specified in Table 716.1(3).

Fire-protection-rated glazing used in fire window assemblies located in fire partitions and fire barriers shall be limited to use in assemblies with a maximum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour in accordance with this section.

Fire-protection-rated glazing requiring 45-minute opening protection in accordance with Table 716.1(3) shall be limited to fire partitions designed in accordance with Section 708 and fire barriers utilized in the applications set forth in Sections 707.3.6, 707.3.7 and 707.3.9 where the fire-resistance rating does not exceed 1 hour. Fire-resistance-rated glazing assemblies tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 shall not be subject to the limitations of this section.
Fire-protection-rated glazing is not permitted for use in fire window assemblies in fire barriers required by Section 1207 of the International Fire Code to enclose energy storage systems.
The total area of the glazing in fire-protection-rated window assemblies shall not exceed 25 percent of the area of a common wall with any room.
Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be permitted in window assemblies tested to NFPA 257 or UL 9 in fire partitions requiring 1/3-hour opening protection in accordance with Table 716.1(3).

diagrams.title: Egress Balcony: Wall Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 1021.2 establishes requirements for the separation between an exterior egress balcony and the interior of the building. In most cases, the wall between interior rooms and the exterior egress balcony needs to meet corridor separation standards, using fire partitions and protected openings. The diagram's left-hand example illustrates this standard situation for a single stairway configuration—architects should design with an assumption that any window or door along the egress balcony must have proper rated protection, as would any opening facing into a corridor.
Single Stairways and Opening Protection
The use of a single stairway is a crucial factor: when only one exit stairway is provided, you do not benefit from the separation exception. This means all doors and windows along the egress balcony must be protected as required for corridors. This is intended to ensure a safe, protected evacuation path in projects where there is no alternate escape route. If openings are left unprotected, it can create a hazardous condition—potential fire and smoke spread from adjacent units or rooms directly to the egress route.

Possible exceptions and edge cases
A common point of confusion arises with occupancy-specific exceptions found in different code sections. While some occupancies may not require corridor protection at certain openings (as listed in Table 1020.2 or elsewhere in the code), this does not generally apply to egress balconies with only one stairway—unless those same occupancies are exempted from corridor separation, the wall and opening protection requirements still apply. For projects utilizing two or more stairways, as depicted in the right-hand diagram, and for layout configurations that avoid dead-end travel past unprotected openings, you can eliminate these wall and protective opening requirements. The key is verifying both multiple egress paths and the absence of dead-end travel conditions for your specific occupancy and balcony arrangement.

children.body: Fire window frames installed with a fire window assembly shall meet the fire-protection rating indicated in Table 716.1(3).

Metal mullions that exceed a nominal height of 12 feet (3658 mm) shall be protected with materials to afford the same fire-resistance rating as required for the wall construction in which the protective is located.

Glazing in fire window assemblies shall be fire protection rated in accordance with this section and Table 716.1(3). Fire-protection-rated glazing in fire window assemblies shall be tested in accordance with and shall meet the acceptance criteria of NFPA 257 or UL 9. Openings in nonfire-resistance-rated exterior wall assemblies that require protection in accordance with Section 705.3, 705.8, 705.8.5 or 705.8.6 shall have a fire protection rating of not less than 3/4 hour. Fire-protection-rated glazing in 1/2-hour fire-resistance-rated partitions is permitted to have a 20-minute fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Vertical Separation of Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
If openings in adjacent stories are within 5 horizontal feet of one another, and the opening in the lower story has a fire protection rating of less than 3/4 hour, the openings must be separated vertically by at least 3 feet by spandrel girders, exterior walls or other similar assemblies that have a minimum fire-resistance rating of 1 hour. The spandrel area needs to be rated for exposure to fire from both the interior and exterior. Another acceptable opening separation is a flame barrier. The barrier must project a minimum or 30" and be of 1 hr minimum fire-resistance rating.

Exceptions:
  1. This section does not apply to buildings that are three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. This section does not apply to buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  3. This section does not apply to open parking garages.

diagrams.title: Fire Protective vs. Fire Resistive Glazing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Diagram adapted from SaftiFirst product literature.

children.body: Glazing in fire window assemblies shall be fire-protection-rated glazing installed in accordance with and complying with the size limitations set forth in NFPA 80.
Glazing in fire window assemblies shall be labeled by an approved agency. The labels shall comply with NFPA 80 and Section 716.3.5.2.
Fire window frames shall be approved for the intended application.

Fire-protection-rated glazing shall bear a label or other identification showing the name of the manufacturer, the test standard and information required in Section 716.1.2.2.2 and Table 716.1(3) that shall be issued by an approved agency and permanently identified on the glazing.
Fire window assemblies shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of this section.
Fire-protection-rated glazing shall be in the fixed position or be automatic-closing and shall be installed in labeled frames.

Approved fire protective curtain assemblies shall be constructed of any materials or assembly of component materials tested without hose stream in accordance with UL 10D, and shall comply with the Sections 716.4.1 through 716.4.3
Fire protective curtain assemblies used as opening protectives in fire-rated walls and smoke partitions shall be labeled in accordance with Section 716.2.9.
Fire protective curtain assemblies used to protect openings where smoke and draft control assemblies are required shall comply with Section 716.2.1.4.
Fire protective curtain assemblies shall be installed in accordance with NFPA 80.

diagrams.title: Weather Protection of Ducts
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior ducts including linings, insulation, coverings and vibration isolation are required to be protected from the elements. If the exterior duct is insulated the duct's protection against the elements must be an approved weatherproof barrier.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 4
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 5
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations: Corridors - Item 1
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations: Corridors - Item 2
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations: Corridors - Item 3
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations: Corridors - Exception 2
Fire Damper Locations: Fire Partitions - Exception 1
Fire Damper Locations: Fire Partitions - Exception 2
Fire Damper Locations: Fire Partitions - Exception 3
Fire Damper Locations: Fire Partitions - Exception 4
Fire Damper Locations: Fire Barrier - Exception 2
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers
Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Wall Assemblies Penetration
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Once hazardous exhaust ducting penetrates a fire-resistance-rated wall, it must be protected with an equal or greater level of fire-resistance rating as the wall, until the point of discharge. However, such ducts shall not penetrate a fire wall. The requirement does not apply when such ducts are internally protected, throughout their length, with an approved automatic fire suppression system. Sometimes called a horizontal shaft, the duct surrounding construction must completely separate the duct from the adjacent area. Where a floor occurs above the three-sided horizontal shaft, the floor assembly must provide equal or greater protection to the floor above.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Hood Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This section applies to a broad set of conditions that do or have the potential to produce hazardous emissions, as identified in section 509.1, including flammable vapors, gases, fumes, mists, or dusts, and volatile or airborne materials posing a health hazard, such as toxic or corrosive materials.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Design
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Hazardous exhaust systems must extend from the point of emissions capture to the building exterior without the potential to contaminate other building areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire area, to reach the building exterior, should be protected by shafts per building code section 713 or horizontal assemblies per section 711.2. This section specifically prohibits hazardous duct systems from extending into or through other duct or plenum systems to prevent contamination of environmental air systems.

diagrams.title: Example: Fire Damper with Grille Detail

children.displayTitle: Section 717 Ducts and Air Transfer Openings

children.body: The provisions of this section shall govern the protection of duct penetrations and air transfer openings in assemblies required to be protected and duct penetrations in nonfire-resistance-rated floor assemblies.

Ducts transitioning horizontally between shafts shall not require a shaft enclosure provided that the duct penetration into each associated shaft is protected with dampers complying with this section.

Ducts that penetrate fire-resistance-rated walls and are not required by this section to have fire dampers shall comply with the requirements of Sections 714.3 through 714.4.3. Ducts that penetrate horizontal assemblies not required to be contained within a shaft and not required by this section to have fire dampers shall comply with the requirements of Sections 714.5 through 714.6.2.

diagrams.title: Duct Coverings: Penetration of Assemblies Prohibited
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a wall or floor with a required fire-resistance rating is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor. Where a wall or floor that is required to be fireblocked is penetrated by a duct, the duct covering is not allowed to penetrate the wall or floor.

children.displayTitle: 717.1.2 Ducts That Penetrate Fire-Resistance-Rated Assemblies Without Dampers
children.titleText: Ducts That Penetrate Fire-Resistance-Rated Assemblies Without Dampers

children.body: The space around a duct penetrating a nonfire-resistance-rated floor assembly shall comply with Section 717.6.3.

Fire dampers, smoke dampers, combination fire/smoke dampers and ceiling radiation dampers located within air distribution and smoke control systems shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, the dampers' listing and Sections 717.2.1 through 717.2.3.

Where the installation of a fire damper will interfere with the operation of a required smoke control system in accordance with Section 909, approved alternative protection shall be utilized. Where mechanical systems including ducts and dampers utilized for normal building ventilation serve as part of the smoke control system, the expected performance of these systems in smoke control mode shall be addressed in the rational analysis required by Section 909.4.
Fire dampers for hazardous exhaust duct systems shall comply with the International Mechanical Code.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Wall Assemblies Penetration
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Once hazardous exhaust ducting penetrates a fire-resistance-rated wall, it must be protected with an equal or greater level of fire-resistance rating as the wall, until the point of discharge. However, such ducts shall not penetrate a fire wall. The requirement does not apply when such ducts are internally protected, throughout their length, with an approved automatic fire suppression system. Sometimes called a horizontal shaft, the duct surrounding construction must completely separate the duct from the adjacent area. Where a floor occurs above the three-sided horizontal shaft, the floor assembly must provide equal or greater protection to the floor above.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Hood Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This section applies to a broad set of conditions that do or have the potential to produce hazardous emissions, as identified in section 509.1, including flammable vapors, gases, fumes, mists, or dusts, and volatile or airborne materials posing a health hazard, such as toxic or corrosive materials.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Design
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Hazardous exhaust systems must extend from the point of emissions capture to the building exterior without the potential to contaminate other building areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire areas. Hazardous exhaust ducts that traverse spaces outside the originating fire area, to reach the building exterior, should be protected by shafts per building code section 713 or horizontal assemblies per section 711.2. This section specifically prohibits hazardous duct systems from extending into or through other duct or plenum systems to prevent contamination of environmental air systems.

children.body: Fire dampers and ceiling radiation dampers that are listed for use in static systems shall only be installed in heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems that are automatically shut down in the event of a fire.
Damper testing, ratings and actuation shall be in accordance with Sections 717.3.1 through 717.3.3.

Dampers shall be listed and labeled in accordance with the standards in this section.
  1. Fire dampers shall comply with the requirements of UL 555.
  2. Smoke dampers shall comply with the requirements of UL 555S.
  3. Combination fire/smoke dampers shall comply with the requirements of both UL 555 and UL 555S.
  4. Ceiling radiation dampers shall comply with the requirements of UL 555C or shall be tested as part of a fire-resistance-rated floor/ceiling or roof/ceiling assembly in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263.
  5. Corridor dampers shall comply with requirements of both UL 555 and UL 555S. Corridor dampers shall demonstrate acceptable closure performance when subjected to 150 feet per minute (0.76 mps) velocity across the face of the damper during the UL 555 fire exposure test.
Damper ratings shall be in accordance with Sections 717.3.2.1 through 717.3.2.4.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

children.body: Fire dampers shall have the minimum rating specified in Table 717.3.2.1.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

children.body: Smoke damper leakage ratings shall be Class I or II. Elevated temperature ratings shall be not less than 250°F (121°C).
Combination fire/smoke dampers shall have the minimum rating specified for fire dampers in Table 717.3.2.1 and shall have the minimum rating specified for smoke dampers in Section 717.3.2.2.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

children.body:
Corridor dampers shall have the following minimum ratings:
  1. One-hour fire-resistance rating.
  2. Class I or II leakage rating as specified in Section 717.3.2.2.
Damper actuation shall be in accordance with Sections 717.3.3.1 through 717.3.3.5 as applicable.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

children.body:
Primary heat responsive devices used to actuate fire dampers shall meet one of the following requirements:
  1. The operating temperature shall be approximately 50°F (10°C) above the normal temperature within the duct system, but not less than 160°F (71°C).
  2. The operating temperature shall be not more than 350°F (177°C) where located in a smoke control system complying with Section 909.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

children.body:
The smoke damper shall close upon actuation of a listed smoke detector or detectors installed in accordance with Section 907.3 and one of the following methods, as applicable:
  1. Where a smoke damper is installed within a duct, a smoke detector shall be installed inside the duct or outside the duct with sampling tubes protruding into the duct. The detector or tubes within the duct shall be within 5 feet (1524 mm) of the damper. Air outlets and inlets shall not be located between the detector or tubes and the damper. The detector shall be listed for the air velocity, temperature and humidity anticipated at the point where it is installed. Other than in mechanical smoke control systems, dampers shall be closed upon fan shutdown where local smoke detectors require a minimum velocity to operate.
  2. Where a smoke damper is installed above smoke barrier doors in a smoke barrier, a spot-type detector shall be installed on either side of the smoke barrier door opening. The detector shall be listed for releasing service if used for direct interface with the damper.
  3. Where a smoke damper is installed within an air transfer opening in a wall, a spot-type detector shall be installed within 5 feet (1524 mm) horizontally of the damper. The detector shall be listed for releasing service if used for direct interface with the damper.
  4. Where a smoke damper is installed in a corridor wall or ceiling, the damper shall be permitted to be controlled by a smoke detection system installed in the corridor.
  5. Where a smoke detection system is installed in all areas served by the duct in which the damper will be located, the smoke dampers shall be permitted to be controlled by the smoke detection system.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

children.body: Combination fire/smoke damper actuation shall be in accordance with Sections 717.3.3.1 and 717.3.3.2. Combination fire/smoke dampers installed in smoke control system shaft penetrations shall not be activated by local area smoke detection unless it is secondary to the smoke management system controls.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

children.body: The operating temperature of a ceiling radiation damper actuation device shall be 50°F (27.8°C) above the normal temperature within the duct system, but not less than 160°F (71°C).
Corridor damper actuation shall be in accordance with Sections 717.3.3.1 and 717.3.3.2.
Access and identification of fire and smoke dampers shall comply with Sections 717.4.1 through 717.4.2.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

children.body: Fire and smoke dampers shall be provided with an approved means of access that is large enough to permit inspection and maintenance of the damper and its operating parts. Dampers equipped with fusible links, internal operators, or both shall be provided with an access door that is not less than 12 inches (305 mm) square or provided with a removable duct section.

The access shall not affect the integrity of fire-resistance-rated assemblies. The access openings shall not reduce the fire-resistance rating of the assembly. Access doors in ducts shall be tight fitting and suitable for the required duct construction.

Where space constraints or physical barriers restrict access to a damper for periodic inspection and testing, the damper shall be a single- or multi-blade type damper and shall comply with the remote inspection requirements of NFPA 80 or NFPA 105.
Access points shall be permanently identified on the exterior by a label having letters not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in height reading: "FIRE/SMOKE DAMPER," "SMOKE DAMPER" or "FIRE DAMPER."

Fire dampers, smoke dampers, combination fire/smoke dampers, ceiling radiation dampers and corridor dampers shall be provided at the locations prescribed in Sections 717.5.1 through 717.5.7 and 717.6. Where an assembly is required to have both fire dampers and smoke dampers, combination fire/smoke dampers or a fire damper and a smoke damper shall be provided.

diagrams.title: Combination Fire Smoke Damper and Fire Damper
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Combination Fire/Smoke Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon the detection of heat and resist the passage of flame and smoke. The device is installed to operate automatically, controlled by a smoke detection system, and where required, is capable of being positioned from a fire command center.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Example (Vertical or Horizontal Assembly)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire Damper: A listed device installed in ducts and air transfer openings designed to close automatically upon detection of heat and resist the passage of flame. Fire dampers are classified for use in either static systems that will automatically shut down in the event of a fire, or in dynamic systems that continue to operate during a fire. A dynamic fire damper is tested and rated for closure under elevated temperature airflow.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 1
Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In California, this exception is only allowed in "...other than Group A, E, H, I, L and R occupancies, high-rise buildings, and other applications listed in Section 1.11 regulated by the Office of the State Fire Marshal. "

children.body: Ducts and air transfer openings permitted in fire walls in accordance with Section 706.11 shall be protected with listed fire dampers installed in accordance with their listing.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Structural Req. and Duct Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Note that while non-hazardous ducts may be allowed through fire walls in certain conditions by the building code, exhaust ducts may not be allowed to penetrate a fire wall in any circumstance. Verify requirements with the adopted mechanical code.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Openings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Any opening in a fire wall is required to be protected. The maximum size of any single opening is 156 sq. ft., but the total length of openings is not permitted to exceed 25% of the length of entire wall. Party walls are not permitted to have any openings. Where the spaces on both sides of the fire wall are sprinklered with an NFPA13 system, then openings are permitted to exceed the 156 sq.ft. limit, but must still conform to the 25% limitation.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers

children.body: A listed smoke damper designed to resist the passage of smoke shall be provided at each point a duct or air transfer opening penetrates a fire wall that serves as a horizontal exit.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A horizontal exit compartmentalizes a building allowing occupants to exit the area containing the origin of a fire into another portion of the building that is protected by fire-resistance-rated assemblies (doors, walls, ceilings, and floors). A horizontal exit separates a space into two exit access areas. Code requirements for horizontal exits address fire-rated separation, opening protectives, capacity, and other features.

children.body:
Ducts and air transfer openings of fire barriers shall be protected with listed fire dampers installed in accordance with their listing. Ducts and air transfer openings shall not penetrate enclosures for interior exit stairways and ramps and exit passageways, except as permitted by Sections 1023.5 and 1024.6, respectively.
Exceptions: Fire dampers are not required at penetrations of fire barriers where any of the following apply:
  1. Penetrations are tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 as part of the fire-resistance-rated assembly.
  2. Ducts are used as part of an approved smoke control system in accordance with Section 909 and where the use of a fire damper would interfere with the operation of a smoke control system.
  3. Such walls are penetrated by fully ducted HVAC systems, have a required fire-resistance rating of 1 hour or less, are in areas of other than Group H and are in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2. For the purposes of this exception, a fully ducted HVAC system shall be a duct system for conveying supply, return or exhaust air as part of the structure's HVAC system. Such a duct system shall be constructed of sheet steel not less than No. 26 gage thickness and shall be continuous from the air-handling appliance or equipment to the air outlet and inlet terminals. Nonmetal flexible air connectors shall be permitted in the following locations:
    1. At the duct connection to the air handling unit or equipment located within the mechanical room in accordance with Section 603.9 of the International Mechanical Code.
    2. From an overhead metal duct to a ceiling diffuser within the same room in accordance with Section 603.6.2 of the International Mechanical Code.

diagrams.title: Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: FIRE BARRIER. A fire-resistance-rated wall assembly of materials designed to restrict the spread of fire in which continuity is maintained.

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 1
Fire Damper Location - Fire Barrier Exception 3
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In California, this exception is only allowed in "...other than Group A, E, H, I, L and R occupancies, high-rise buildings, and other applications listed in Section 1.11 regulated by the Office of the State Fire Marshal. "

diagrams.title: Fire Damper Locations: Fire Barrier - Exception 2
Fire & Smoke Damper Locations - Fire Wall & Fire Barriers

children.body: A listed smoke damper designed to resist the passage of smoke shall be provided at each point a duct or air transfer opening penetrates a fire barrier that serves as a horizontal exit.

diagrams.title: Horizontal Exits
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A horizontal exit compartmentalizes a building allowing occupants to exit the area containing the origin of a fire into another portion of the building that is protected by fire-resistance-rated assemblies (doors, walls, ceilings, and floors). A horizontal exit separates a space into two exit access areas. Code requirements for horizontal exits address fire-rated separation, opening protectives, capacity, and other features.

children.body:
Shaft enclosures that are permitted to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings shall be protected with listed fire and smoke dampers installed in accordance with their listing.
Exceptions:
  1. Fire dampers are not required at penetrations of shafts where any of the following criteria are met:
    1. Steel exhaust subducts having a wall thickness of not less than 0.0187 inch (0.4712 mm) are extended not less than 22 inches (559 mm) vertically in exhaust shafts, and an exhaust fan is installed at the upper terminus of the shaft that is powered continuously in accordance with Section 909.11, so as to maintain a continuous upward airflow to the outdoors.
    2. Penetrations are tested in accordance with ASTM E119 or UL 263 as part of the fire-resistance-rated assembly.
    3. Ducts are used as part of an approved smoke control system designed and installed in accordance with Section 909 and where the fire damper will interfere with the operation of the smoke control system.
    4. The penetrations are in parking garage exhaust or supply shafts that are separated from other building shafts by not less than 2-hour fire-resistance-rated construction.
  2. In Group B and R occupancies equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, smoke dampers are not required at penetrations of shafts where all of the following criteria are met:
    1. Kitchen, clothes dryer, bathroom and toilet room exhaust openings are installed with steel exhaust subducts, having a wall thickness of not less than 0.0187 inch (0.4712 mm).
    2. The subducts extend not less than 22 inches (559 mm) vertically.
    3. An exhaust fan is installed at the upper terminus of the shaft that is powered continuously in accordance with the provisions of Section 909.11, so as to maintain a continuous upward airflow to the outdoors.
  3. Smoke dampers are not required at penetration of exhaust or supply shafts in parking garages that are separated from other building shafts by not less than 2-hour fire-resistance-rated construction.
  4. Smoke dampers are not required at penetrations of shafts where ducts are used as part of an approved mechanical smoke control system designed in accordance with Section 909 and where the smoke damper will interfere with the operation of the smoke control system.
  5. Fire dampers and combination fire/smoke dampers are not required in kitchen and clothes dryer exhaust systems where dampers are prohibited by the International Mechanical Code.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Shafts: Duct & Air Transfer Opening Penetrations - Excpt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a shaft is allowed to be penetrated by ducts and air transfer openings, the openings are required to be protected by listed fire and smoke dampers unless the conditions of one of the provided exceptions are met.

diagrams.title: Hazardous Exhaust Duct Systems - Incompatible Materials and Common Shafts - Exception
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
To avoid chemical reactivity within the exhaust shafts, separated or diluted exhaust systems are required to remove hazardous exhaust streams from the building. The requirement applies to all hazardous exhaust systems, like dip-tanks, spray coating, combustible dust, fume hoods or other operations producing hazardous exhaust streams.

The Fire Code defines incompatible materials as: Materials that, when mixed, have the potential to react in a manner which generates heat, fumes, gases or byproducts which are hazardous to life or property.

The exception to 509.4 applies only to "laboratory exhaust systems." Per Section 509.1, a laboratory shall be defined as a facility where the use of chemicals is related to testing, analysis, teaching, research or developmental activities.
